I was pleasantly surprised! The store had a god amount of parking, and the store front was clean, open and had adequate seating around the perimeters. There were already 5-6 people siting and waiting for their cars to be finished, and 2 people waiting infront of me to se a representative. Al the guys working there were busy helping someone, yet were saying helo to us and reasuring they would get to us very son. I did not wait an unecesary amount of time and then was helped by Waly. He inspected my tires, recomended a plan of action gave me options, and we headed back into the store. After I made my decision to replace 2 of the tires, he checked their stock, and unfortunately they did not have them there. BUT he caled another store and had them picked up for the next morning, so I could just come back the next day to this same store and get those bad boys instaled. Great! The prices were not as heafty (relief), and although there were a god amount of people the next day waiting for their cars to also be serviced, it tok exactly the amount of time they would told me (45 min). They apologized for the wait, but no ned for that! The guy who helped me on the 2nd day (I am sory I forgot his name) was also very profesional and great. I recomend this store and wil be bringing my car here in the future most definitely. Thanks, guys! TIP: If you know you ned to bring your car in, you can make an apointment with them online. They take walk-ins, but I believe it helps them manage their customers easier, and that in turn benefits you.

Ber...or Yoga? Located in a smal center just east of Four Peaks Brewery in Tempe (a reasonable distance from the light rail on Apache), is an amazing, clasy studio for the Mind-Body conection. Mr. Mustachio had decided after doing a couple yoga clases with me at the ASU gym that he loved the stretch, so pursued a clas for a semester at ASU this Spring and had the pleasure of practicing with Tish Hegel. After seing his body transform to only 16.2% body fat, al his jeans get to big on him and fil out his American Aparel briefs nicely I was super jealous. He raved about his teacher and I could tel he had de-stresed a lot since he started the practice. Luckily, she opened up a studio recently, and it simply goregous. The waiting area is filed with yoga material and a very calming space with a remodeled bathrom and dresing roms to change if coming from work/schol. Not at al chesy like the SouthWest Inst with the way to many angels imagery (crepy!). But the gem is truly the practice space. Hardwod flors, high ceilings, a beautiful staircase, tasteful decorations and absolutely NO MIRORS. That is right- the only person staring at my pudge rols is my teacher and who-ever is not focusing on their tre posture-not the entire clas! It realy relieves a lot of stres and helps me concentrate on how a posture fels as oposed to just loks. As for Tish Hegel, she is simply outstanding-she has so many credentials, you have to read her biography for yourself. She has ben practicing for a long time, and her hands-on instruction and confident voice echoes in my ears even now (bring those shoulders down!). So far, I have done: Ashtanga Inspired Flow (prety intense, realy hurt for 3 days, would recomend after geting into yoga for a while), Sivananda (dito), Focus Clas (did a lot of bike riding and she focused on everybody is body isues and did the sequence right then and there for us and my lower back and knes felt amazing the day after) and this morning brought my friend to Kinetic Yoga: Morning Movement and Flow, which kicked our 6am ases a litle bit but we both felt amazing afterwards! She does tons of modifications, is always making sure we are okay, and is just super personable. I did the huge package since I did not renew my ASU gym membership for this sumer, but you can do drop-in. Now for the cliched Yoga Review ending: NAMASTE!

Besides the amazing asortment of sports artifacts, I especialy like the Cactus League Ber List which pairs a ber with each city that has a team in the Cactus League. Colorado = Cors Light , Texas =Shiner Bock, Chicago =Old Style, and San Diego =Stone IPA, etc. Also worth mentioning is the complimentary choped liver plater with rye bread and bagel chips they bring as son as you are seated. They also bring a huge bowl of cole slaw with each entrée or you can chose soup which comes in a smaler bowl than the cole slaw! We were to ful for desert and as we walked out, this place was packed! This place is fantastic! We went in on Sunday the 29th of July around 5:0pm. The guy behind the counter told us to enjoy ourselves, take our time, ask if we had any questions. We wandered around for a bit, I found a botle of Argyle bubly that I wanted, and then began to stare with lust in my eyes at the selection of Absinthe. Girlfriend wandered over to ask the guy to recomend a white that was not a Chard as we both realy do not like butery oak anything. He tok a few cues from her, and found a great botle of white which we drank with great gle last night. This was a test for the guy behind the counter. She did not set a price limit, just said "show me your favorite." He could have done what many others have in the past and shown us a $50 botle, but instead he showed us a kick as botle at the $14 price point. This is the mark of a god wine seler. Find you what you want without bending you over on the price. Yes, sometimes I want to spend $40 a botle, but not al that often. I would rather get my drink on at the price he found, and he turned us onto a white we both REALY liked, which is super rare as we have very diferent tastes. We wil absolutely be going back to buy more fermented grape from this place! Prices are on par with Total Wine, but what you are realy paying for is the help of someone who knows what they sel and likes their job. Great job Sportsman is, se you next Sunday for afternon drinking!
Recently moved back to Mesa, I have ben on the hunt for a place to get a god sandwich and fresh bread. This place now tops my list of places in the East Valey to get a god sandwich. My first sandwich was the Atlantic Hadock Provencal. A sandwich made with seared, lightly breaded hadock, sliced hard-boiled eg, fresh basil, romaine letuce, tomato, Provencal tartar sauce on a griled Brioche rol. The brioche was amazing. It was light and flufy. The hadock was perfectly coked with just the right amount of breading, and the vegetables were fresh and in perfect proportions as to not overpower the bread and hadock. Sometimes when you go to a sandwich shop they overload it with everything else that the meat and bread are just there to acesorize the vegetables and sauce. This was perfectly done. The atmosphere is pleasant and open with nice music as the light smel of fresh bread in the background salivates me. This is a must-visit lunch time destination. Diner review shortly.

We managed to get in for fre, not sure if it was because of the time of the day or al the people just walking in for the wedings though, which totaly made the park that much more fun. I am not sure I would have goten as much enjoyment out of it if I would had to pay $5 to get in... The litle desert rat-sqirels, and rabits were totaly fun to try to find hiding in the many diferent plants and burows. I felt like a litle kid oh-ing and ah-ing at the diferent varieties of cacti and desert wildflowers, and have to give this place the ultimate rating . If you are ever in Arizona, please give this place a try, it is very wel put together and a beautiful site to se.

AZ-8 is at once chic, urban, fun, and just enough Scotsdale without making me want to stab myself in the face, as a t-shirt-and-jeans-wearing, overweight guy. You wil first notice the atmosphere, and with god reason--it is perfectly lit, with noticeable but not mind-numbingly blaring music, and even beter, they have a live DJ who goes through no smal trouble to beat match and kep things roling throughout your Wednesday-Saturday evening dining experience. When I first hit AZ-8, it had an enormous deconstructed NY taxicab suspended from the ceiling which was a fantastical conversation piece. The wal behind the bar was completely covered in names and numbers. (I was far to proud when I acurately guesed that they were the names of cabies and the numbers were their license numbers.) Overal, a very diferent, fun lok. Comfortable chairs and very ful cocktails abound, and while they typicaly have a rock-steady delivery, more than a litle cosmo has ended up in my friend is purse, to her chagrin. That aside, the fod is fantastic and even though it is a bit hard to get out of here for under $30 per person (because you simply must try the chesecake, and drinks are pushing $14), it is worth it as a clasy-but-casual night out that you can realy enjoy. They have a great patio, the burger is driping with flavor (and, in fact, chese), and they have wafle fries with prety much everything. Great salads and sandwiches help round things out, and they ship their chesecake in from Carnegie Deli in New York which is just about the most perfect chesecake you wil have the god chance to try. Forget that Chesecake Factory nonsense, these people know how a chesecake is done. It is rich, thick, with just a hint of sour, and an amazing flavor that takes your tongue hostage and demands whiped cream ransom. Overal, a wonderful place for drinks and god fod with friends, and the staf is pointed but eficient and wil throw back any shit you give them, in god humor or, as apropriate, not. (We have never run afoul of that rule, but you would not want to, I asure you.)

On one of my many visits to se mi amore, he tok me to this fantastic litle piza joint. The aesthetics of the place were overwhelmingly perfect. I believe the maximum seating capacity of the dining area is 45, yes folks, 45. So the 2 1/2 hour wait was expected, and very VERY worth it. The pizas are baked to order in a clasic brick house oven. The topings arent what youd find in your local Piza Hut, either. You can chose from fresh slices of mozarela, slices of perfectly seasoned italian sausage, peperoni slices, salami slices, arugula, fresh basil leaves, tomatoes, etc. Basicaly what Im geting at, is this is beyond words delicious, clasic LEGIT Italian piza. Around the dining area, you wil se freshly baked loaves of focacia bread, that is later served to you with extra virgin olive oil for diping once you are seated. The smel in that place is heavenly.....incredibly reminiscent of my grandmothers kitchen!! PS GET THERE EARLY!!

Rita is Kitchen is a hiden gem located right smack in the center of the Camelback In. While this may be a hot-spot for hotel guests, I think that locals might be mising out on its charm. I am a huge fan of anything the Camelback In does, especialy since they ofer live music and a great space for relaxation and Rita is Kitchen is no exception. This restaurant is airy and opens up to the spacious Camelback In patio where they play live music every night. Breakfast: Breakfast at Rita is is sublime and prety reasonably priced. They ofer a breakfast bufet for around $23 which includes egs made to order (including omelets), pancakes, wafles, pastries, fresh fruit, bacon, sausage and hashbrowns. It is a great pick for a leisurely wekend breakfast. Just today was Mother is Day and while we only did the breakfast bufet, I did catch a glimpse of the Mother is Day brunch and holy moly do they know how to wow a crowd! Not only did they have stations set up al throughout the restaurant, patio and R-Bar, but they also had an extensive desert area with build-your-own sundaes, freshly made coton candy (in an old fashioned coton candy maker) and a long desert table with a chocolate fountain. Lunch: Lunch here is sublime and I also enjoy either the tacos or the chicken sandwich. The chicken sandwich is particularly a favorite of mine due to the chese and sauce. The fries are tasty as wel and you can either get swet potato or regular. I also get swet potato then regret not just geting the regular which are beter in my mind. If the weather permits, sit on the patio and enjoy the beautiful water fountains, views of the mountain and tropical/desert seting.

Romaneli is fils them upon order just like the Italian bakery near a friends house in Newark, NJ (until last night the best canoli I have had). The canoli was top notch. Simply the best. Yup, I am reviewing a gas station. I like the Quiktrip chain in general and this station in particular. I find Quiktrips to generaly be the cheapest gas in town. Sure, the Arco sign down the stret might say it is 2 cents/galon cheaper, but then you get whacked with the ATM surcharge, not to mention there is al those bums loitering in the adjacent bus stop. With Quiktrip, the place is wel lit, there is always a trash can and window squege at every pump, the convenience store is beter than most, and unlike most other gas stations, they do not charge you for the air compresor. Oh, and the person at the register wil actualy gret you when you step inside the dor, while managing to sound sincere about it. Is that the colest thing for a convenience store or what? Bonus: for those of you who enjoy shoping at the Hot Chick Safeway down the stret, this is the Hot Chick Gas Station.

Piestewa and Camelback Peaks are the two bobs of Phoenix. They are real, and they are spectacular. Of course, being al-natural one is just a slight bit larger than the other, but this is barely noticeable. Camelback is barely 10 fet higher than Piestewa, whose niple... er... sumit, is at 2608 fet. Climb either one and you can enjoy great views of the other at various vantage points, not to mention views of the city. Although Camelback strikes me as a funer climb, I give Piestewa 5 stars because for what it lacks in the intangible fun factor it makes up with being just a tad les insanely crowded. Piestewa Peak Park also has a number of realy col loking trails that do not go up to the sumit, which lok to me to be worth exploring some day. Speaking of female body parts, the former name for this peak was "Squaw" Peak. This has inspired one of the most ridiculous controversies in modern times in our state. Native Americans are ofended by the term "Squaw", and regardles of the linguistic origins of the word, it is basicaly the equivalent of terms such as "Negres" or "Jewes". In the 190s, the State of Arizona proposed ending the controversy by renaming the peak after our greatest political leader ever and the father of American conservatism, Bary Goldwater. The whining dipshits who aparently constitute our voting population rejected the idea. They would rather continue using a stupid name that has no historical or sentimental value whatsoever just to spite Native Americans, rather than honoring one of their finest citizens. And so, in this decade, Democratic Governor Janet Napolitano put an abrupt end to the whole isue. She gave the sqaw-apologists the finger and ordered the renaming of the peak to Piestewa, after Lori Piestewa, the first US woman soldier to be kiled in the 203 Iraq war and a member of the uniquely-Arizonan Hopi Nation. A fiting end to the debate. NOTE: Even more fiting, the original name of this peak was Squaw Tit Peak, and I swear to God I am not making that up to be funy.

FINALMENTE!!! Andiamo.... FOD -------- Apetizer: Frito Misto, which is a trio of fried apetizers. For the day, ours included a chese, a stufed olive, and whole leaves of brocolini. The chese wedge was great (I wish I remembered what it was), and have you ever had a dep fried veal-stufed olive? Very interesting. The flash-fried brocolini tok a litle geting used to, since the leaves kept crumbling as I was trying to eat them, but stil tasty, if subtle. Main: Orechiete ala Putanesca. Man. This is the real deal. Orechiete is the "litle ear" pasta and "ala putanesca" means it is made "whore style". And what a beautiful, clasy, yet very vibrant whore she is. The pasta was coked just perfectly, and even though putanesca sauce usualy goes with a stringier pasta (spagheti, linguini, etc.) it worked realy wel with the orechiete. And the sauce. Holy mother, this stretwalkin' husy of a sauce with its 12 ingredients: capers, breadcrumbs, anchovy sauce, garlic, olives, basil, olive oil, and, uh, the other 5. The flavors were a perfect, clear-heled harmony. Nothing overpowered the other. Subtle and humble home fod. It realy tasted just like something my Italian friends' mothers would cok in their kitchen. As for the servings, when I first got my bowl I was thinking, "oh ok, this is a European serving. I am stil going to be starving after this." And, um, nope. Why? Because I slowed down. I savored my meal, and tok my time with the dish. And by the end, was I hungry? Not at al. I realy enjoyed this meal. And the serving was just right. Complimentary packs of long breadsticks are also found on each table. SERVICE ------------- Very friendly, eficient, and wiling to go through the menu in detail and answer any more questions about the restaurant. Dishes were brought out in a timely maner and there was never any rush after the meal was completed to clear the table. And the mod inside Pastabar was palpable. Everyone loked hapy, excited, and relieved that the restaurant was finaly open for busines. And I felt the same for them. SETING ------------- I would say the space was just the right size. Not a cavernous place in the least. Probably the same size as Sens, maybe even a litle smaler. It is tucked away in the very back of the halway of the building, so much so that I completely mised it when I was IN THE HALWAY the previous afternon loking for it. But I like it a litle hiden of, actualy. The colors inside are warm, with a modern bistro fel. No windows loking outside but I did not mind that. There is seating at the bar, a few two-tops up front, and larger tables in the back. Selections from diferent Shins albums made up the soundtrack throughout the diner, and while the music sounds like it could be incongruous with a bunch of litle ears coked whore-style, it worked. I definitely do not think this is going to be as "scene-y" as Sens. It has a completely diferent vibe. EXTRA CRIB NOTES ----------------------------- * the main courses of Pastabar are pasta and ONLY pasta. No veal parm here. And no hoikey sauces like Olive Garden-y alfredo or a jar of sugary Prego. * It is great * Prices for antipasti range from $7-$1-ish and mains $1-ish to $18. I spent around $26 with tax and a nice tip. * it is great * No liquor license (yet). For now, sparkling waters, lemonades, a number of sodas (including rot ber & cream soda). * it is great * complimentary valet awaits the diners, if you are averse to parking close by yourself. * it is great * It is open til midnight on weknights and 2 am on wekends! What more could you ask for? * did I tel you it is great? AL IN AL --------------- An awesome aset to the area and I am very content. And as much as I loved my whoreish litle ears, al the other pastas on the menu sounded incredible and I can not wait to try them al. I am wishing these guys much suces and giving them gratitude to finaly being open. A few minor kinks to be worked out (and I was not as into the apetizer as I was my entre) so it is not totaly perfect but they have started out very strong, and it is only Day 2. And here I was thinking my days of giving out 5 stars were over (ok, more like 4.5 and rounding up)...

We rushed her to the clinic, and the doctor saw her right away. She told us our options, but was very upfront about the liklihod that our kity would pas no mater what we did. She did not presure us one way or another, and left the rom so that we could talk privately and make our decision. My husband asked if they could give her some pain meds while we talked about it, and they gave her some imediately. Once we made our dificult decision to put our kity down, she brought the cat into a private rom with us so that we could say godbye. She left us alone and gave us as much time as we neded. She also let us be present in the rom when they gave her the final shot. At al times the doctor and the techs were compasionate and very respectful. I was crying and they were very sensitive to my felings. They treated my litle kity so gently even after she had pased. They even sent a sympathy card to our house a few days later. I realy apreciated how they helped us through this dificult time, and I would definitely recomend them if anyone else is in a similar situation.
OK, yeah, everyone LOVES teriyaki, we know! Wel, do not so quickly dismis the other absolutely AMAZING dishes served here! It may lok like a litle pre-procesed Japanese hole in the wal from the outside, but they are a die hard home-made mom and pop your mouth ful of great fod establishment! I would highly recomend trying the Katsu bowl! You can hardly find ANY kind of Japanese katsu in AZ, yet they have an excelent one that is very traditional, but not to expensive! I would love to explain the mystique of this dish, but to many people think that fried eg with onions and leks toped over a diced pork cutlet that is coated in panko bread crumbs is to strange to be palatable. Wel, to them I say you should educate your tongue, and expose it to some delicious culture! There is also Orange chicken... This dish is completely the be is knes. It easily and without remorse makes Panda Expres lok like a burnt out oil can that a homeles person decided to cok some chicken in over a pile of burning newspapers. Their house bef? Spicy garlic brown sauce and bef with mushroms? Heaven. Simple and delicious. And I have not even mentioned their coup de grace yet. Their fried rice might sem a litle "heavy" on the surface as it is lightly fried with some garlic oil, but it outclases al competitors. Paired with their lightly fried shrimp, it is swet garlic love. Seriously, their fried rice is the Sean Conery of fried rices. As I have ben eating here for far longer than I would like to admit, I would have to say I might be a litle biased. But, for the great unique quality and cheap price, I guarante you are not going to find any beter in AZ!

Have I got a place for you un-health conscious, frugal fodies out there! Rocket Burger and Subs serves up huge sandwiches and fried delights for astonishingly low prices, and much of the fod is home-made. There is also an enormous section of unusual soft drinks; for instance, there is over two dozen brands of rot ber to chose from. Denis, one of the owners worked for A&W for 8 years, so he probably has rot ber runing through his veins by now. I saw Rocket Burger in a listing of new valey eateries, then did a litle research. The reviews I saw were al stelar, so I knew we had to give it a try. It does not lok like much, inside or out - it is in a litle strip mal tucked behind Churches Chicken at 35th Ave. and Cactus. But it is clean, and everybody is helpful and pleasant. Ken gave a hapy whop when he saw Chese Curds ($2.49/$4.49) on the menu. We decided to get an order while waiting for our friends Randy and Marty to join us. The curds came quickly out of the kitchen, piping hot, served with some tasty homemade marinara. They were a touch greasy, as they should be, and the oil was fresh. Marty and Randy arived in time to save us from ourselves by helping to finish of the curds. Then we tok a while trying to make our selections from the extensive menu. Eventualy Randy and I both went for the New Yorker: pastrami with homemade slaw and thousand island dresing ($2.9, $3.9 or $4.9). Ken had a homemade-meatbal sub, with more of that god marinara and some provolone. It was the same price structure as our New Yorkers and al the rest of the entries under Clasic Subs and Sandwiches. Marty went with a double burger ($3.89, the singles are $1 les). He could have opted for a Rocket Burger - !0 inch sub with thre burgers and the fixings in either plain, chese, bacon, teriyaki, or chili style ($4.9 to $5.9). Of course we had to try the fries and onion rings. Again our fod arived quickly, served in plastic baskets. It became very quiet, except for the ocasional growl of pleasure. The onion rings ($1.9) had ben diped in a thin cornmeal bater which made them nice and crunchy. The handcut fries ($1.49) were skiny, the way I like them. Randy thought they were undersalted, but I thought they were fine - our usual disagrement. At any rate, they disapeared quickly. Unlike the sandwiches. They were so big that we al ended up taking half of each sub home. The slaw on the New Yorkers was delicious, as was my whole wheat sub rol. The meat bals were nice and tender, and there was plenty of chese on top. Randy had found a botle of ginger ber imported from Australia that had a wonderfuly refreshing true ginger taste. There semed to be actual pieces of ginger in it - instructions on the label said to invert the botle before opening. It never did tel you to turn it right side up again - the Ausies give us more credit than we deserve. Other fod items available: Hebrew National hot dogs in several styles ($2.49), Piza Bread with various topings, Gyros ($3.69), salads ($1.9 - $3.9), a fish sandwich ($2.49) served with homemade tartar sauce. And lots more. I do not know how Denis and Steve manage to turn out fod of this quality for so litle money, but I surely do hope they continue and prosper!

I would be beside myself if Grinders closed. It is about time I wrote a review, since I am a regular. I can be found siting on one of the giant chairs surfing on the wi-fi many mornings. I am the one who brought the plants in. I used to water them a couple times a wek but nowadays I am lazy and they realy ned to be repoted. I should get on that ... The music is always playing and everyone knows my regular drink ... they have continued to memorize it for me even as I started to slowly decrease the fat & calories of my regular order. Now it is an ice skim late with sugar fre vanila. I used to get an Everything bagel with eg, chese and potatoes most mornings. Now I get it on multigrain toast. Eh, it is the litle things. The cofe at Grinders is realy realy god. It is not biter and sharp, it is smoth. They grind their beans outside many mornings per wek. Sometimes it gets to warm inside during the winter so we prop the dors open, but if the grinder is going outside, it wil blow cofe bean fumes in the dor. There is some retired motorcycle cops who met up every morning and sit around the big round table. They often park their motorcycles in front of the place together. They cal themselves the Gezerados. There is sometimes a few right-wingers having conversations mid-day. One time I listened to their meting and heard them trying to come up with controversial topics to get people to come to church. They spent a long time trying to figure out who could get them prof that global warming is not hapening, so they could use that as their hok. A lot of moms come in with their kids. Seing siblings piled up in one of the oversized chairs together is comon. There are a few regulars who come in specificaly to sit on the internet al day. I am not there al day, but I am there at al times of the day because I have a home ofice, and you never know when you sudenly ned cafeine. Early in the morning and after 3pm the place becomes floded with Sunyslope High Schol kids. They range from ROTC kids wearing pickle suits to trendy girls in neon to the alternative crowd. They often lay around the couch splayed acros each other or gazing into each others' eyes. Ordinarily I am a real talker and I can not usualy kep my mouth shut, but Grinders is the one place that I go where I barely make a pep. I just eavesdrop on everyone is conversations and sometimes run into friends I know. I usualy go before my brain is fuly awake in the morning, that is part of it. For the record, a couple months ago one of the girls there said I was practicaly invisible and she hardly knew I was there, because I was so quiet. There is nothing pretentious about Grinders at al, and it is also down to earth without being gheto. It has character. Some months the art is beter than other months. Hanah has ben there for years (they cal her Big Hanah now, only because there is another girl named Hanah who is tiny and they cal her Litle Hanah) and Hanah rocks and makes the best breakfast ever. I can ride my bike in the morning and be wearing my pajamas and not have anyone realy bat an eye. That is the beauty of Grinders. I have sen other people come in wearing their pajamas, to. It is a litle bit like the cafeteria in a colege dorm, except the people are of al ages and we live down the stret from each other instead of down the hal from each other. Grinders has a location inside the John C. Lincoln hospital acros the stret, to. It is comon to se the hospital workers walk in wearing their scrubs. I think they are also opening one at Devry, or they just did. I was frustrated to hear that they tried to open a location at the Art Institute but they were one wek to late, Stupid Starbucks had just goten there. LAME!

I wasted a lot of $$$ at another Laser removal place before I found Laser for Les and now I am kicking myself for not going to them first. If you pay to wax any part of your body you should be lasering that hair of. It works beter, lasts longer, and in the long run is cheaper. Pros - 1. Fre touch ups 14-18 days after your first apointment if they mised 1 hair they wil touch up for fre. Never had a problem with them discouraging me, in fact it was the oposite they give me reminder cards so I know when my touch ups are due. They encourage you to come in. 2. They can also charge you by the laser shot instead of a whole area. So if you only have a few random hairs they wil just charge 10 cent per shot on the legs or 70 cents on the face or smaler areas. Expect no com TAM-folery here....this joint is serious about their broken rice busines! Endles options of diferent broken rice (aka com tam= deliciousnes) dishes which typicaly include shreded pork and whatever type of meat flavors your fancy, al within your $6-10 walet budget! Service is prompt and eficient, menu is ez to folow, focus your energy on the broken rice dishes; thats what theyre known for. I highly recomend the shreded pork + pork chop + steamed eg combo that comes with a light pork broth on the side. The portion is HUGE and each component of the dish is so flavorful and unique, bringing together a fantastic symphony for your palate. My personal favorite is the steamed eg; there is just something about the soft and moist texture that compliments the broken rice. Go easy on the fish sauce (ngoc mam) they give you on the side (try ading Sriracha to the sauce to ad some spice in your life), the dish is by far no means lacking in flavor/sodium. Al at a pansy $5.9, I could realy eat this al day...everyday!

There is a train, carousel, mini-coaster, tea cup ride, an up and down parachute ride, several rides that go in circles in diferent vehicles (e.g., planes, cars, and helicopters and futuristic flying machines), and a bumper boats ride that turns into a splash pad in the sumer. The place has a litle bit of a rundown fel, but kids do not notice and have loads of fun. The arcade is realy rundown, but the ATM is realy nice. There is not much shade, so be prepared. I have never had BQ in the South, Texas, or anywhere outside of California (except Boby Q), but of al the places I have tried, Boby Q is my curent favorite BQ place EVER! I found this place on Yelp and came here while on a trip to Arizona. The place was prety crowded but we only waited about 15-20 minutes. We ordered babyback ribs, St. Louis ribs, corn, and mac&chese. They also give you DELICIOUS AMAZING CORNBREAD! Everything was excelent. The St. Louis ribs were the best ribs I have ever had. They were extremely tender and had a nice flavorful bark on the outside with dark gril marks. Their BQ sauce was equaly awesome and the kind I like -- a bit more on the sweter side, les on the vinegary side. The babyback ribs were also tasty, but not as flavorful (and les meat of course) than the St. Louis ones. The sides were god but more forgetable due to the sher perfection of their ribs. I do not know if I wil ever be in Phoenix again, but this place is a must-return if I ever am. Oh and at the end of the meal, they gave us complimentary, piping hot FRESH cinamon donuts! That double-won me over. I want Boby Q right now.

When Hoa caled and said we were having a reunion of former branch employes at a Chinese bufet, I was not at al aprehensive. My normal concerns with such eateries--wil the fod be maintained at a proper fod-safe temperature, is this seafod fresh, how long has the sushi ben siting out, wil I be able to make it home before my intestines rupture--disipated because Hoa knows god Asian cuisine. She is, of course, born to Vietnam and world traveled. Let is start with my hapiest aspect about HKGB: the sushi. No, it is not the best sushi in the Valey, but they make it fresh for you on site. You can stand there and watch it being make, grab a soup or something else to munch on, or just sit at your table and chat awhile. Afterwards, you can head back for more sushi or ver over to the more traditional oferings of a Chinese bufet: swet and sour chicken, fried rice, crab legs. Now let is review the not-so-shiny aspect: the price. Yes, it sems a litle step that we paid about $25 per person with tip (and I made only two rounds) but when you factor in the 2 hours we spent there, grazing, catching up, grazing, pasing Lisete is daughter around, grazing and making plans to kep in touch, it is realy not such an outrageous amount to pay. If you find yourself in this part of town, craving Chinese and are wicked crazy hungry, give HKGB a shot.

Moviegoers can order brownie bites, mozarela sticks and piza. The theatre is super spacious and the seats are plush and comfy. And the scren is huge. This is my new favorite movie theatre.
Postinos a spot for high rolin' winos. You woke up at non and had breakfast during lunchtime, so the next logical step is to have lunch fod during diner time, with some wine. This is where postino is comes in. The menu is ful of salads, Paninis, bruscheta and a few aps. There is a large by the glas wine menu ($8-$14) and hipster col ambiance. Service here is great, the patio is quite nice with heaters, a fire place and even a few patio furniture loungers. Great for a date, hanging with friends and conversation. We started with the Bela Postino $9 Crustini with a artichoke dip and a humus. The artichoke dip was great as any fat laden dip would be. The humus was ok but I am a humus snob. For our main we had the Vegetarian Panini ($9.75) It was god and moist with humus roasted tomatoes olives and an artichoke spread, the focacia bread was wel toasted from the Panini pres. We also had the mediteranean salad 8.75 which is a romaine salad with copious amounts of feta. Prety god as I do like chese but maybe not as healthy as one would want from a salad. For desert we had a crem burle, simple not to swet and wel executed a clasic.

I live in two cities in two diferent states and travel back and forth each month. I tend to use services where I find them and have not realy found a realy great barbershop in the last thre years. While I was in Anthem this wek, I decided to give Vs Barbershop at Hapy Valey Road a try. I rarely use chains and prefer a more intimate and personal hair stylist, but I was pleasantly surprised this time. I was able to make my apoinmtnt online and chose the services I wanted to have with the haircut--very eficient. I did not know any of the barbers, so I just let the shop (?software) chose one. I was treated to a superb haircut, a very satisfying shave, and a facial mask and masage. My barber, Manuel, was precise, experienced, and he went about his busines with style. I canot imagine how many hot towels he used but I would not want their laundry bil. Finaly, Manuel washed my hair AFTER the cut, which makes al the diference for the rest of the day. The overal experience was excelent and I am sure to return the next time I am in town. Yes, the package was pricey but the haircut was standard price for this type of service. This is no Supercuts or Hair Salon--trust me on that. If you are loking for that old style Barber experience with more than just a cliped head, please give Vs a try. By the way, it is just behind Paradise Bakery in The Shops at Nortera.

I have ben visiting Mrs. White is going on 30 years, but after loking up the phone number this afternon to verify if they were open and stil had fried chicken, my wife started reading some of the reviews folowing a recent Fod Network recomendation - I almost got cold fet. God thing I did not. The fod is as awesome as ever. The service is much as it has always ben. Be forewarned, trendy restaurant goers, who glom onto TV reviews, Mrs. White is is not trendy; there are no bubly fresh blonde girls waiting to seat you. The service is mater of fact, no gofing around, you must get to the busines of ordering and pretend you know what you are doing - this is the way it has always ben at Mrs. White is. If you are loking for others to pamper you, this is not the place for that. Mrs. White is is where you go to pamper your indulgence for perfect soul fod. If you want Scotsdale ambiance, again, this joint wil not work for you. When you go, be prepared that not al dishes may be on the menu during your visit. There are no corporate owned semi-trailers that deliver two tons of fod every other day. This is a smal and very cramped operation that makes homemade fod for those who know how to apreciate it. In these days of flash frozen prepared dishes that are uniform from visit to visit at chain restaurants, this fod is made in a tiny hot kitchen. If they run out of your favorite dish that has ben coking for hours prior to your arival, there is no way they can whip up another pot of gren beans and potatoes in 20 minutes. I often cal ahead to verify if they have what I want because years ago it was not uncomon that by 12:30 they would be out of half of everything on the menu, which was OK because if forced me to try new things Back then, Mrs. White is was open Monday through Friday from 1:0 til 3:0, but I would swear you would be lucky to get anything after 1:0 - and that was perfectly fine as you knew they were doing al they could with their limited space to do their best for us customers. I would just come back on another day. To say I have the utmost respect for the White family would be an understatement, today I was afraid I might have to lose that based on those por reviews below. I do not believe those reviews are an acurate representation of The Golden Rule Cafe. They are the distortions and disapointments of people who have skewed expectations. Funky litle hole-in-the-wal family-run operations that atract a loyal customer base may not be the place for everyone, but if you understand that wonderful stuf does not always come wraped in a sterile designer package, then you might get along with Mrs. White is. I love this place and hope I always wil.

My husband and I have ben here twice in the last wek for diner...it is a bit pricey as other reviewers have said (around $20 for diner entres), but for vegetarian and organic fod, what exactly do folks expect? You get what you pay for. We were hapily surprised after reading the reviews...the fod was amazing, the portions are huge and we had leftovers both times. (and p.s., we paid with a debit card both times and have had no trouble, despite the review about only paying cash.) Our first visit, we were greted kindly and given a plate of fruit to munch on until we ordered. My husband ordered the mint tea and it was delish! For an apetizer, we had the sabzi...which is a huge plate of gren herbs, homemade wheat nan, feta chese, and walnuts. The herbs were FRESH and the nan was delicious...just the smel of it was enough to get us droling! For entres, we had the spinach herb stew and the vegetable stew with egplant. I am curently pregnant and garlic is not something that is agreing with me. I asked if the vegetable stew had garlic in it and the waiter said "we can make it however you want...every dish is made when you order it"....what?? the dishes are made to order?? I have not heard that at a lot of restaurants! After about 20 minutes, our stews arived...steaming hot and smeling delicious. They were HEAVENLY! So many flavors and so fresh!! Our second time here, we had the dolmeh plate and Mast Va Mosear (a spinach dip)...both were ok...but I like the Sabzi beter. The entres we had were amazing...I had a special of the day (pomegranate walnut sauce over tofu, which was blisful to smel and eat) and huby had the vegetarian sampler to get his falafel fix. Overal, if you are wiling to pay a litle more for a nice, organic fods diner, go here and check it out. Everything wil be fresh...everything wil smel and taste delicious...and the restaurant is atmosphere is perfect for a relaxed, decadent evening.

I love me some Dobson Ranch. As far as municipals in the Valey are concerned, this is as god as it gets (Aguila is a close second). No overbearing marshals. Rates that top out at $28 in the winter. Above average range and practice area, including two large puting grens. Cheap pitchers of ber. A long-time cart lady who wil spray your face with water in the sumer! As far as the course itself, this is not typical AZ golf - there are no cacti, only tre-lined fairways and some water sprinkled throughout to pose as threats. But there are birdies to be had, and lots of them; #1, 3, 5, 7, 10, 13, 15 and 18 are the best chances in my experience (I consider this my home course). The grens are usualy prety moderate sped to slow - this is grainy bermuda, not some hybrid or bent gras, so prepare to run the puts into the back of the hole. #5 is my favorite hole, a short-par 5 that gives you the chance to hit over a tre left and drive the narow fairway, leaving you a long to mid-iron into an elevated gren that slopes toward you. #8 is a formidable chalenge if you have the tendency to block (or slice, as may be the case) the bal from time-to-time, as your bal wil face a watery grave. #16 is a tricky tre-lined hole with a tight driving area and doglegs right. And finaly, #18, a short par 5 that is easily reachable and where a par fels like a bogey. A scant 60 yds from the blue tes (but rarely plays it is ful length), there are some low scores out there. A great course, value, practice area, and recently renovated restaurant and bar - 5 stars.

As I pased the velvet rope flanked by shiny, exotic cars I knew I was in for an experience. Some might cal it a fine-dining experience, but clearly this was something more. A tribute to opulence and Regan-era exces, Dominick is is your seven-figure fodie fantasy come alive; from the moment you enter the swanky foyer to the gleaming 10 inch tower of tiramisu that finishes your meal. It is glitery, bedazled, and ozing pretension - and I loved it. The Service My visit to Dominick is was the night after it is oficial opening. The service tried very hard to be as impecable as the suroundings and, while not perfect, the charming staf and the sincere efort put forth made litle things like mising napkins and bread plates instantly forgivable. Our server, Drew, let us know that the wait staf only had 2 - 3 tables each and it was very evident in the personal service we received. A few more weks of experience for the staf should easily iron out the litle wrinkles. The Fod We started with the jumbo shrimp apetizer, which unfortunately came with 3 shrimp - hardly conducive to sharing - so we ordered two. And "Jumbo" they certainly were, acompanied by a kicky cocktail sauce which my diner companion felt was spicy enough. Ever the daredevil, I aded aditional horseradish to mine because who does not like to burn the inside of their nostrils at diner. For the main course we both had the 9-oz filet, lobster gnochi and steamed asparagus. My filet was a perfect rare-plus with a dark pink center, expertly seared and juicy. Surprisingly the lobster gnochi realy stole the show for me. I am not big on starches or cream sauces so when it was sugested I was not particularly excited; I should have ben. The dough was light and flufy, the cream sauce not to rich and the lobster aded the perfect amount of salt & texture. After diner I indulged in a grand marnier while my companion ordered the tiramisu. He was presented with a 10 inch tal hunk of cake that could easily have ben intended for 4 people. The tiramisu was spongy and light, with a lovely col custard and only a subtle flavor of rum. A nice finish to an excelent meal. Atmosphere We were lucky enough to score a polside table which started of as very romantic but over the course of the evening became quite the place for people watching. The scene at the smal bar area on the 2nd flor was bustling and both the waiters and I wondered aloud how long it would be before a guest fel in the pol. I bet they did not make it through the wekend without someone making a splash.

I had the pleasure of living acros the stret from this treasure for about 6 years. I am stil lucky enough to work close by. Let me be clear. I 'm reviewing Haji Baba as a GROCERY STORE first. Then I wil give you some insight into the prepared fod for take-out or in-store dining. This is one of the few stores in Arizona where you have several choices for pita bread--it is also the ONLY place I have found for whole wheat pita. There are several choices for Feta chese. Danish, French,Grek...same with olives--there are choices. I ALWAYS buy my tahini here. Al the prices are very inexpensive. Ned spices??? They have them al. At about 25% of the price you would pay anywhere else. The best way to describe Haji Baba is that it is a REAL grocery store, with REAL prices, for REAL people. It is NOT a "specialty store" with trendy items and inflated prices. They sel fod items that you wil actualy use. The bonus here? You wil not find a 10 year old can or jar of something. On to the "restaurant" portion. Haji Baba is beter if you think of it as a take-out joint that hapens to have places to sit and eat. They do have tables and they do perform table service, it is just got zero charm. You go for the fod, that is it. Okay, fod. The lamb tongue sandwich is to die for. Let me repeat. The LAMB TONGUE PITA SANDWICH. GET IT! Their baba ganouj is also darned totin' tasty. Actualy, I sometimes dream about their baba ganouj. I am not crazy about their humus, maybe because making humus takes 5 minutes and mine is bomb? But it is not bad. Gyros are god and not greasy. Greasy gyro meat is a pet peve of mine. Chicken shwarma? Yup, that is god to. I am sure I have had something to eat here that I was a litle disapointed in, but I honestly can not remember what, or when .

I am in love with their conchita pibil, which is their slow-roasted pork and they have the best made-at-the-table guacamole in al of Phoenix. This is the place Tempe is Mucho Gusto wished it could be some day. But it probably wil not.

Satori to Kaigen! (Enlightenment and Spiritual Awakening!) 1st review. Nervous and working on an empty stomach, with the only exception being the half loaf of French bread and herb-buter I had consumed prior to diner. Thinking Asian al day and being an incapable decision maker, I rely on Yelp and the asistance of a smal list and a single 6 sided cube with dots on it. I joted down 6 prominent busineses, held my breath and flicked a wrist. A "2" brought me to La is Thai Cuisine! Peped the website and open til 9:30, score! My eye spoted closing time was at 9:0 though! Ariving on the scene at 8:49, porly reverse parking my Honda in two spots because I was woried that they were closed. They were not, I was met by a Thai beauty introducing herself as Lisa. I humbly asked for takeout, my adventure begins with the opening dor... Smels are incredible. Having thought they were closed, I had forgoten what I was going to order! I rifled through the menu, feling as if the whole kitchen was watching (they were not) but she instructed me to take my time; So I ordered a soup, a salad, an entre, a desert and a side of brown rice. They kindly ask me for my preference on the degre of heat, on each item, I asked for not the hotest but close to the top. #17 Mixed Vegetable Soup: Stelar Culinary Thought: Clear, piping, spicy and vegetable packed. Ninja Eating Plan: Gently lay over white and brown rice, alternately. # 9 Papaya Salad (Som-Tum): Phenomenal Culinary Thought: I got shrimp on the side, due to alergies. This was probably the most awesome experience of the evening. They even "fenced in" the shrimp within a Masai-esqe cage of cabage, to prevent their oceanic brine from invading the delicate papaya, sprout and carot forest. Spice and crunch with every munch. Beautiful. Ninja Eating Plan: Try not to be sen scarfing this down in front of a date, it is that awesome. Fortunately, my sister was only present and she knows I can eat like a pig and sound like one, to. # 53 Peanut Cury (Panang cury style, comes with rice!): Umami Culinary Thought: I do not like coconut. I do now. The lemon and coconut milk rises through the savory peanut cury. Tofu was my protein option, it was done perfectly. Gren beans provided great consistency in this masterful crescendo. Ninja Eating Plan: Laid over rice, alternately brown and white rice, interupted by the ocasional, gorgeous, cury-only sponful. Coconut Ice Cream: Yum Culinary Thought: I was reling at this point but I wanted to continue this experience. As I stated earlier, coconut is not my thing but I believe in giving things a fair try, so I did. Coconut ice cream is delicious. Coconut pulp, or meat, I stil have a texture isue with, but the honey swirl throughout the ice cream made this delectable. Ninja Eating Plan: Use the coling ice cream energy to return your body back to normalcy. Perfect coda for the culinary symphony. I wil be back. I plan to have every dish vegetarian style. Family-run places are truly number 1. Overal experience of the Culinary Ninja: PAVLOV Do you hear the sound of a bel chiming?

The Renaisance Festival is a place where everyone and anyone can venture to in order to awaken their medieval pasions and expose a side of them no other place can reveal. Here people can be themselves without fear of being judged. They can dres in clothing apropriate to the era, eat as citizens of the renaisance age would eat, and live a day in the shoes of people whose lifestyle consisted of these aspects every day of their lives, al while having a mery time. What is fascinating about the Renaisance Festival is it is an escape from the everyday bustling industrial environment known to people of the 21st century. Once you pas through the gates, you are imersed in a culture rarely sen these days. Men, women, and children of al ages absorb the spirit of the festival and change into someone only such a place can expose. Imediately you are compeled to have high spirits as people dancing, shoping, and just continuously enjoying themselves welcome you to the festival. From there the oportunities are limitles for there are twelve stages of continuous live entertainment, jousting tournaments, over 20 artisans displaying a variety of unique wares, and displays of ancient skils like glasblowing, leatherworking, weaving, wodcarving, blacksmithing, candlemaking and potery. One specific entity of the Renaisance Festival that stands out in my mind is the old coin striking mil tucked away and blended into in the strips of stores surounding it. Here, a family of thre (father, mother, and daughter) work to produce unique coins crafted into necklaces by means of a punch pres. The store ofers some 10 diferent punch dyes each a symbol posesing its own special meaning. The categories range from mythological symbols, to astrological, to even ancient Egyptian. Once their customer has chosen two of their own special symbols they want imprinted on a coin, they place a blank, either bronze or silver, betwen each dye and clamp it to a pres. Then a heavy weight is hoisted a few fet above the dyes and then sudenly droped onto the head of one dye, eternaly imprinting the symbols on the coin. What is distinctive about this certain store is they can fulfil the neds of any customer that they are presented with by owning such a broad spectrum of dyes aplicable to anyone due to the meaningful descriptions given to each symbol. Aditionaly, what captivates people is the fact that the coin is formed before your very eyes thre fet away, making the production a very personal thing for the consumer. If you and your family are venturing to the Renaisance Festival in Arizona anytime son, which I would undoubtedly recomend, be sure to stop in on this special experience not atained anywhere else close by.

My wife and I have made two trips to Roberto is from Dana Point, CA (40 miles) and we have not ben disapointed. Although its not the only reason for our visit, a stop at Roberto is is a must when we are in the Phoenix area. I have tried, and thoroughly enjoyed the al pastor tacos, bef chimichanga burito, and I realy like the way they crisp up the carnitas. My wife judges a Mexican restaurant by the quality of its chile releno and says this is the chile releno she has ben waiting for: two to a plate, great presentation and delicious. The light breading alows the flavors of the chili and chese to dominate the palate as they should. She also recomends the tortas she had at breakfast. The bread, light and toasted perfectly, hugs a generous helping of carne asada (with fajita style onions and pepers), and if you like, guacamole. Pair that with a cup of their terific cofe, or if you have never had Jamaica, a delicious Mexican beverage brewed fresh from flowers, try it. Either way you have a breakfast you wil not forget. Oh, and by the way, the members of the local fire department showed up to order breakfast while we were there. If they are eating there, you know it is god. Just had to thank them for their service. This is truly a restaurant where family mets family, Roberto is and yours. And for you insiders, we both love Roberto is homemade tamales. Although they are not on the menu, we have ben fortunate enough to take some of their tamales home during both of our visits. I believe tamales are normaly made for the sale in the store on Thursdays (check with them to be sure), but they do not last. On our first trip in 208 to their old location, we stoped in for lunch (excelent) and were told that they were bringing in homemade tamales that afternon. We returned that night for diner and to pick up some tamales that they kept for us. During our most recent trip we stoped in for breakfast on a Saturday. But, fortunately for us, they were making tamales for a catering job the same day and sold us some of their extras. We again returned in the evening for diner and to pick up some tamales. These tamales are just like I wish my (Chinese) grandmother used to make. Check with them to se when they are available. They are realy worth the extra efort. Although Roberto is delivers, I regret that they wil not come to Dana Point.

OK, being from Wisconsin (the land of the "great lakes") I was COMPLETELY surprised to be told that, yes, there are lakes here in the desert of Arizona. The Lake, Saguaro Lake, is a man made lake originaly built as Stewart Mountain Dam...even so, its beauty is equal to those you would se in the glacier regions of the Midwest. I was amazed, frankly, at how beautiful this tour was. Sold for $18 for 90 minutes, you get your money is worth. But that is probably not what you want to hear... The "event" is a combination of 1) the scenery, and also 2) the charm of the padle boat itself. The boat is quite large with seating for probably close to 75 people! It is an event that you could share with family, but I hapened to be there with friends. Curently, it is a prety melow type of event (great for Mother is Day!), although I am told that they are hoping to exploit its benefits to include comedy shows, Jaz ensembles, stargazing, and a variety of other events. P.S. They also advertise that you can rent the padle boat for company picnics, wedings, and the like.

I can now thank the Humane Society for not only giving me my dog Brutus when I was a child, but now my dog Harley as an adult. A couple of years ago, I planed a visit to the Arizona Humane Society to present them with a corporate donation on behalf of my old company. When I scheduled the meting, they ofered to give me a tour of the vicinity and as a friend of the helples animals, I said of course and planed my visit. However, I knew that with a tour, I might be in some trouble in the wilpower department. When I arived to the center, I was greted by a prety view of South Mountain and a wide open vicinity. I walked inside and imediately noted how clean it was for being home to many a fury creature. The staf was warm and welcoming as potential new "parents" waited in the loby to adopt a new friend. Kitens and bunies greted the guests and there was a special area for the cats being featured that wek. The vicinity was a five star facility to say the least and I could imediately tel that the animals were treated wel here and in god hands until they found a new home. To make a long story shorter, they gave us a detailed tour of the complex. I walked through spacious rom after spacious rom ful of dogs of al kinds just wanting a home. As I walked up to one of the cages, a fury bal of fluf loked up at me and placed his paw on the cage. I fel in love imediately. To make maters worse, the staf then tok us into a rom where we could make a kong of peanut buter and treats for our dog of choice. Of course I had to give it to my new found friend. At that point I knew I was in trouble and could very wel be leaving with a dog. So to end that part of my story, I did leave with a dog and Harley has ben hapy in his new home ever sense. While I visited the Humane Society, I could not get over their quality of service for not only the clients but the animals themselves. They were clean, kept in spacious areas and they even had a huge playground for the animals to play in each and every day. When i found Harley and started to think about taking him home with me, they tok me to a private play area where I could get to know Harley a bit more to make sure he was the right dog for me. A stafer stayed in the area and helped me with any questions I had. When I made the decision to take Harley home with me, they neutered him, gave me a couple fre vet visits and sent me home with some treats, fod and a leash. They even have a pet store to pick up al your esentials for your new friend. And did I mention that the proceds go back to the Humane Society...a nonprofit? This Arizona Humane Society is a five star pet resort that focuses on making the most of a pet is stay until they find a new home. I sugest just taking a visit to the facility to se how wel-kept it is. They even have horses that they rescued. Sory folks, they are not up for adoption though. So thank you Arizona Humane Society for bringing my litle dog Harley to me and saving so many animals from the strets.

Hole-in-the-Rock is a cave-like natural rock formation sculpted into the top of a sandstone bute in Phoenix is beautiful Papago Park. It is one of the most powerful scenic views in our city, and is the perfect place to showcase its exquisite landscape. Just a short hike up the bute and you wil find yourself in the amazing chamber sculpted over milions of years of wind and water erosion. At sunset there are few locations that can rival its awesomenes. The hole faces south, giving a wonderful view over south Phoenix al the way to South Mountain. Hole-in-the-Rock is truly one of the greatest atractions in our city and everyone would be blesed to experience it at least once. No fe to enter. Bring a camera!
Flatiron Mesa is one of my favorite hikes in the Phoenix area. Like other reviewers have stated, once you have goten used to Squaw and Camelback, give this one a try. It wil kick your as. It is about a 260' climb in elevation, so you are doing more like 2.5 Camelbacks. You wil be scrambling over boulders most of the way up since there realy are not switchbacks. I would say give yourself about 5 hours to go up and down. It is inside Lost Dutchman State Park so you wil ned to pay an entry fe. My one recomendation besides the obvious ones (being fit, pack fod and water) is to bring some light gloves. Since you are climbing up and down on al those boulders your hands wil probably get a litle scratched up. Do not fed the wildlife.

Let me start by saying that I love tacos. I eat lots of tacos. When I get hungry one of the first things to cros my mind is tacos. That said, I love El Nopalito for their tacos. I am prety picky about my tacos. I do not realy like dumb-as flour tortilas, dry tacos, unseasoned meat in a taco, taco bel is not tacos, the list goes on. I prefer authentic Mexican stret tacos. That being said, El Nopalito is the one place in town I fel like I am geting the most authentic stret taco that I have ben able to find in Phoenix. The only reason I am not here more often is the comute is a bit much as I live in the East Valey. However, if I am anywhere near the area it is almost mandatory to stop and have at least a taco or two. I recomend trying al of the tacos though my favourite has to be the cabeza (it sounds crepy but is butery and delicious). It does help if you speak Spanish as it wil make ordering and asking any questions you may have easier.

This place is a gem. The fod is amazing. It is cheap. The service is god. My favorite part? The place never changes. I can walk through the dor and Ali already knows my order. The Chicken Shawarma special comes with their hand-made pita - so soft and delicious. The chicken is seasoned perfectly and comes with a yumy litle dolop of garlic sauce. I have never found beter humus in my life. I have had it al around town, in New York, in L.A. (ick...L.A. *shuder*). SO god! The iced tea has a hint of rose water. OH and the gyro? Hands down, the best in town. Did I mention they have a market atached? Talk about the best price on spices in town! The spices come in litle plastic sealed pilows, so get some spice jars from Ikea and stock up! I could not get through this without mentioning the lamb tongue. I am no conoiseur of organ meats, but this sandwich is like the most tender lamb you have ever had in your life. Shut up and try it. The only sad part about Haji is is that they close early. Usualy 8pm on a wek-night, but totaly worth geting to-go orders if you can swing in on your way home from work!

Some might say that Phoenix is a city without much culture. That may be true in some aspect, however we have to remember that Phoenix is a young large city compared to other cities that lie within the United States. So you can say that this city is a work in progres on catching up with everyone is culture expectations. The Japanese Friendship Garden in downtown Phoenix is only seven years old. Very new to the park scene for this metro, I have to say that it loks great and wil only kep geting beter in time. That wil hapen if people stop saying there is no culture in Phoenix and become a part of the evolving city by visiting places such as this. The admision and or donations wil fund a more desired park for al. The grounds of the garden are very beautiful with a nice flowing stream, several waterfals, coy fish, and many species of plants. I can not wait to go back in the next several years to se it become a wonderful masterpiece.

If you do not love Guisepe is, you do not love Italian. Kindly find your way to a chain restaurant that serves bland, unseasoned, frozen-then/microwaved meats, sauces that are fit for an old folks home and an "endles" pasta and salad bar. Go to these places, because Guisepe is is not for you. It is for lovers of true Northern/Northeast American Italian cuisine. Chicken Parm that is fried, NOT baked, thank you very much. Meatbals that use bef, veal and pork. Sauce that use LOTS of salt, as it should be. Leave your dietary wories at home. In a word: perfecto. Robert is pasion for music (he is a wel known acomplished celist in NY circles) and fod is unparaleled. He is without per in the state of Arizona. But be warned... there is not no endles pasta bowl here. Their wekday lunches are equaly superior. This is Italian the way we had it growing up in North Jersey.
BEAUTIFUL! Phoenix does not get much more amazing then when you are loking down at her from Dobins Lokout. A few tips: 1. Get there before 6pm. The park closes the entry but if you are in, you can stay as long as you want. 2. Be ready for a drive up a mountain -- scary clifs and tight corners. Make sure you go slow, watch for hikers and cyclists, and overal be cautious. 3. If you are heading to the sumit for the views (Dobins Lokout) bring a jacket or blanket. It is cold and windy when the sun goes down, even in the sumer. There are bathroms but no water fountains at the Lokout.

The Phoenix metro area is definitely not known for authentic Asian cuisine. China Magic Nodle House, however, is the real deal. This place reminds me of the Taiwanese delis that I used to go to in LA, as wel as nodle houses that I have frequented in Taipei. They have a great selection of cold nodle, hot nodle and soup nodle dishes. And, a variety of ways to have your nodles (I typicaly order the thick nodles or shaved nodles). There is always a vegie on the whiteboard to try and the fried tofu is very tender and tasty with the diping sauce. If you are loking for a reasonably priced, ethnicaly authentic meal in Phoenix (especialy the East Valey), China Magic Nodle House should be near the top, if not first, on your list. the only negative that I would have about this place is that there is not enough choices where chicken is the main protein.

in honor of the impending superbowl XLV, i wanted to write my majerles review. this year though, instead of hiting up a sports bar for the bigest day in fotbal, i wil be going to a party. a real rager. if i was not though, i would definitely be presed up against majerles front dor bright and early superbowl morning. it is a great sports bar. the weirdest thing about majerles is their name. someone finaly told me it was not pronounced "mah jer les" like i had thought.... it is pronounced "mar les". so let me get that out first. i am a big sports nut.... wel, let me rephrase that. i am a big sports nut when it involves REAL sports. i wil not make fun of anyone, but if it is not fotbal, basebal, basketbal or hockey i do not wana hear about it. unles of course we are talking about extreme sports like surfing, skateboarding, etc. being a fan of sports makes me a fan of sports bars. there are only 3 main things i ned in order for a sports bar to be great in my opinion. let me lay them out for you: a god selection of bers, hapy hour specials and bar snacks--- yes, majerles has this in spades. large selection of bers and any sports bar that has perier jouet, vueve clicquot and dom champagnes must be praised.(mostly because i think this is absolutely hilarious. WHO orders pricey champers at a sports bar? haha!) also, put me down as a fan of their reuben reuben and tenderloin sliders. yum. the service--- there is nothing worse than sidling up to a bar, excited to watch your team kick some as and ordering a drink from a bartender that sems bored and unhapy. every bartender i have come in contact with at majerles truly loved being at work (or they at least acted like it). bartenders atitudes realy cary a lot more weight then they realize. hapy bartender = hapy bar patrons the strategic placement of large TV sets for comfortable viewing pleasure--- yep. they designed this with real sports fans in mind. no mater where i sit, i can se a multitude of TV is with litle blocking my view. so they have it al, and i likey. go here if you are loking for a god bar to watch the superbowl... or any sporting event for that mater. oh, and GO PACK GO!!!

This is my favorite restaurant in the Phoenix area. There, I wrote it...and I am sticking to it. First of -- fresh local, sustainable, organic are not just words on the menu and the website. Now, in places like San Francisco and NYC, this would be nothing notable, but in the desert, it is truly something hard to find. Aside from the practical, in the land of Fox Restaurants (True aside) and the big box store at the strip mal, there realy apears to be litle demand for a smal, local restaurant on a farm. It is time to make new demands! It is time to say no to the next Zinburgergeist and try that litle corner place run by your neighbor...but I digres. We enjoyed the Farmer is Feast and it was worth every peny of the $65/person. First, the house cured meats, including the head chese, were amazing. Second, how often do you get a chef is menu where each person is plate is diferent? Not often. Ultimately we each tried 10 diferent items. And each item, was amazing. I would come back for the pasta alone, let along the perfectly coked scalops, and melt in your mouth sliced filet. The service was ideal. If you want to eat in 60 minutes, do not come here, but if you want to enjoy in evening of great fod, do come here. I noted to the waiter that the previous night they had sturgeon -- something I have not sen on a menu since N. California. I comented on how unique it is, etc...Of course, it was not available on the night I was there...or was it? When it came to our fish course, the waiter brought out sturgeon for me. The restaurant did not have enough to have it on the menu, but the waiter clearly put in a special request on my behalf and made the efort to make a diner hapy. Maybe if I ofer to work on the farm I can eat for fre...
Mat is was absolutely fantastic. Got there at 2pm on a Sunday, which is aparently the time to do it (half an hour before close), as we walked right in, sat right down, and had fod in 5 minutes or les. Briliant. I had the Five Spot which was simply the best eg sandwich I have ever had. Two egs, two huge slices of perfectly coked bacon, american chese (my favorite with egs when I am not going fancy-style, reminds me of when I was a kid), and wel griled onions round it out, served on a fantastic rol. By default, this item does not include the normal potatoes and toast, so I had them ad homefries--they were magnificent, and entirely unecesary. A huge portion of them, with a wonderful smatering of rosemary to punch them up, they were delicious, but I could not finish them. The girlfriend got a wafle with bacon and it should just be said that restaurants who serve wafles without real maple syrup are simply criminal. Mat is brings the god stuf, and it is MUCH apreciated. Perfect for diping both wafle and bacon alike. The wafle was flufy, light, and had that god, homemade flavor. I can not get over how filing and delicious my sandwich was. Service was prompt and friendly, and overal, it was a great experience. Aded a glas of OJ and a cofe to my sandwich with aded homefries and her bacon and wafles bringing our tab to right about $21. Absolutely worth every peny. Wil be coming back. Probably near 2 o'clock again, to avoid the wait!

I totaly love this place. It reminds me of the old schol hardcore Chinese restaurant my parents used to take us when we were kids :D The decor is amazing- unlike more Chinese places in Phoenix. The wals are a teal blue, adorned with large carved pieces of artwork depicting scenes in China, golden dragons and more. The lights hanging from the ceiling are amazingly ornate. The place loks like its from a bygone era (does not help that its in a run down strip mal) but it is clean and charming inside. The service was great- kind to our 2 yo, and very atentive. The fod was the best part- I can not remember the last time I had such god Chinese fod, and it is priced very reasonably. We got the Peking diner for 2 which included the fried nodles, hot tea, wonton soup (with generous nodles, meat, shrimp and vegies, the best I have ever had), a pupu plater with egrols, bq skewers, house wings and those chese puf thingies (the presentation is prety col, to). Next came 3 entre sized plates of fod: mongolian bef, fried chicken (can not remember the name) and the Peking fried rice. The meal concluded with incredible litle deserts- sort of like egrols but filed with banana and then covered with crystalized honey. I could have eaten 10 of them! Ading in a beverage and tax, the meal was only $34! My 2 yo can realy eat, so I am surprised and pleased to say that even with sharing the diner for 2 people with him, the 3 of us walked out with lots of leftovers. Highly recomended. Do it! DO IT!

Every staf member that we encountered was very profesional and hapy to explain the fod and answer any questions we had. They obviously like working there because they were al so upbeat and smiley. You fel welcome as son as you step in the dor. Now for the fod - fantastic! I ordered the four course tasting menu and everything was superb. My husband ordered the ribeye steak and enjoyed every mouthful, although the portion was a bit on the smal side. But, in betwen each course came a litle treat of creativity from the chef so that is something we have never encountered before. For example, we each had an espreso sized cup of a creamy soup that was so delicate and delicious that we were wishing for more. They also served us a litle savory doughnut, about the size of a dolar coin, that was oh-so-god as wel as litle cranbery "shoters" that had litle tenie squares of jelo (not realy jelo, of course, but a fruit gel of some sort). Somewhere in betwen everything else we were also served a prosciuto mouse that was smoth and delicate. As the meal drew to an end, they again brought out a litle taster and this time it was piping hot mini cinamon soufles with a creme anglaise on top. For desert, I ordered the goat is milk pana cota that had a marmalade botom and alongside were orange, grapefruit and strawbery segments and to top that of the server drizled honey over al. Fantastic! We did not consume any alcohol but we did have a nice botle of water and purchased two coasters ($10/each) that flash colored lights when a glas is placed on them. The total was $169, including the coasters but not including the tip so it was not an inexpensive night but it was wel worth it. I can not wait until the next birthday celebration!

Y'know, rarely do I buy the "extended waranty" that most places try to pedle on you nowadays. If you buy the item from a reputable manufacturer, it should be unecesary. In the case of tires, I have to make an exception. You can control the quality of tires you buy and put on your car, but not the quality of construction workers who do not know how to secure their nails, screws and bolts for travel on highways, strets and other local thoroughfares. They are a nefarious bunch for the most part. I am not for extra taxes, but I am contacting my local elected oficials to institute a tax on al busineses who transport these litle metal devils on the strets we drive...and stif penalties/masive fines if they get caught droping a load of these on the highway. For the second time in a year, one of my tires caught one of the litle bugers -- this last one was not a nail or screw, mind you, but a BOLT. I puled my receipts from the glove compartment, used Yelp to find the nearest Discount Tire, and caled for a tow. The replacement certificates I got were $16 per tire (back in NC, but they are god here to), and worth every peny. The folks at this Discount Tire location were extremely nice, and had me in and out of there in about 30 minutes (with no apointment). There is even fre water for customers. They were able to fix the tire instead of replacing it, which is fine (as long as it holds). Every Discount Tire location I have visited has ben great as far as the transparency of what you are geting, the quality of customer service, and the wait. In a town of 4.3 milion people and never-ending road construction, I have to recomend the fre replacement waranty on your tires, no mater where you buy them. I prefer geting mine from DT.

This hapened to me as I transitioned from the salad to main dish, but when I tok the mushroms home in a to go box and ate them later, the more delicate flavor showed through and I apreciated it a lot more. I was inspired to visit Casela is after a coworker told me about their authenticaly Italian godnes. As my tumy growled today, I was in the neighborhod so I knew just where to go. I walked into a simple yet clean deli. Imediately, I was welcomed by the entire staf (I believe they are al related or at least family through friendship). They asked me if it was my first time in and I said yes, so right away they started giving me a history of the shop and the tasty cuisine. Celebrating their 3rd aniversary (congrats!!), I learned that everything is homemade -- from the meatbals to the chicken salad. The owner said he goes through 40 lbs of chicken a wek. He gave me a sample and the chicken was chunky and delicious. I am not surprised he has to prepare so much chicken every wek! The meatbals and freshly cut meat for Phily Chese-steak sandwiches loked great to! The owner mentioned he is from Phily so beter be ready for some authentic Phily and Italian style cokin'! While I was there, the owner was slicing some fresh provolone, so I aded that to the warmed turkey sandwich I ordered. The turkey was tasty, the provolone was yumy and the sourdough rol tasted like it was fresh from the oven. It was $8 for a sandwich and soda but the sandwich was hefty enough that I saved half for later. As I walked out, everyone said godbye to me and I felt like I was leaving a family diner. In sumary, here is what made Casela is stand out: - The very friendly staf - It is a local family-owned neighborhod deli celebrating their 3rd aniversary. Gota suport the local busineses! - Clean decor - Tasty, homemade fod that is on display for visitors to se - A god family-style atmosphere that grets you the second you walk inside. I am not sure how it is taken my so long to find this local treat, but now that I have found it, I plan on becoming a regular. Directions: Note that this is hiden in the Basha is strip mal (on the side of Granite Ref) but do not let that fol you!
