Unlike other reviewers, I did not like the bufet, though my friends from work think it is a god value. However, I have ben going for diner to Flavors of India for nearly thre years now, and have ALWAYS liked the fod. FOI is my first choice for Indian cuisine in Phoenix, out of the four other Indian restaurants in the valey I have tried. Yes, FOI is in a strip mal, but once inside, the ambiance is pleasant. It sems quite clean, I never got sick from anything I ate there (that is saying a lot, as I admit to being a fusy eater), and the waitstaf is helpful. Bolywod videos on the large flat-scren wal display in the corner are an unusual feature, but the volume is low or completely muted, so you can watch or chose not to, it is not distracting. (Here is a fotnote about that: I ate at FOI on the night of the presidential primary election. My dining companion noticed that most of the waitstaf was gathered around the TV in the bar, watching electoral results, so he asked our waiter if we could watch to. After geting the enthusiastic okay from the two other ocupied tables, it was quite late in the evening, silent Bolywod was replaced by live news coverage with volume turned on). Regarding the fod: I love their matar paner (coked peas in a tasty curied gravy, with smal cubes of homemade mild-tasting chese). My super-spicy friend gets the lamb vindalo (super-spiced as he requests). Tandori shrimp, chicken and tika masala are god though a bit pricier, the samosa apetizer (lightly batered and dep-fried cut vegetables) is fresh, warm and crunchy. Regular and garlic nan bread are everything they should be, biryani rice is overpriced (I would stick with basmati rice as a side dish), and swet lasi (a wel-chiled dairy drink, similar in taste and consistency to a vanila yogurt smothy) is a nice treat. My spicy friend says his gin-and-tonic was weak, and they do not have ingredients to make a Blody Mary, but hey, FOI is an Indian restaurant, so I can not fault them to much for that! Other pluses: open a bit later than many Phoenix restaurants (seating ends at 9:30 pm); very fast with takeout orders; there is lots of parking; the 16 North bus stop is nearby; silverware, glases, white coton tablecloths and napkins are always spotlesly clean.

There are 3 choices at ASU for game design. Which one you chose depends on why you want to study game design. 1. Polytechnic = Games are an enginering problem. If you are interested in the enginering of games - go there. The colege of technology and inovation htp://interactive.asu.edu/?q=hom 2. Tempe = Games for (Education, Medical, Legal etc) They are closely tied with the education department and the Games for Impact initiative. htp://cidse.enginering.asu.edu/ 3. West = Games as Art (Fine Art) If you want to explore games as a medium and art form this is where you want to go. You can either get a BA -htp://newcolege.asu.edu/harcs/degres/majors/interdisciplinary-arts-and-performance-program or a BS htp://newcolege.asu.edu/mns/degres/computing/aplied-computing-program

I violated my rule of avoiding grocery shoping while hungry and decided to venture over to Whole Fods. Whole Fods tends to be the indecisive individual is nightmare (that would be me). Yet, this store is a fodie is dream. There are aisles upon aisles of glorious, wholesome products (pun intended). Everything is meticulously organized and there are at least ten varieties of every type of item. No joke. It tok me fiften minutes to decide which brand of botled tea would be suitable (and economical). I roamed the freshly prepared fod section like a vulture circling it is prey...strategizing which choice would be the best taste sensation. Did I want a made-to-order wrap? Or a glas of wine and a couple tapas? (the live music was aluring)...Maybe sushi? Piza? Salad bar? Soup? Maybe something from the smokehouse...oh! A cupcake from the cupcake bar? On and on it went. My final decision was sushi. The spicy tuna rol tasted fresh, and the Pacific salad rol was very crisp. I also grabed a container of ginger for $1.9--not the artificialy preserved pink variety--al-natural pickled ginger. Blis. I purchased some cucumber salad from the salad bar as a side/palate cleanser. Al in al, a very satisfying meal. Prices are a tad higher than your average grocery store. Then again, it is Whole Fods. A word of advise: come with a game plan (e.g. a shoping list). If you do not define what it is you want prior to entering this store, you wil end up spending two hours and twice as much money than you anticipated.

Once we went to Grimaldi is in Hoboken, NJ and were not al that impresed. Yet the first time we ate at this Grimaldi is, we were blown away! Upon entering, you are enveloped by the aroma of piza baking in a coal-fired oven. This is swon-inducing---and I mean that in a god way. The smel almost has you believing that you are in a piza joint with a coal-fired oven in the Northeast. When ordering piza baked in a coal-fired oven, I like to get a plain chese piza. IMO, this is the best way to fuly taste the sauce, chese and crust without anything else get in the way. There is nothing like a thin crust piza from a coal-fired oven with that char on the crust. The crust has just the right balance of crispy and soft. The sauce is wel flavored with proper proportions of basil and oregano. The amount of chese is just right. I love to savor each and every bite. There is more to this Grimaldi is than the one under the Broklyn Bridge. This one has other items in adition to the piza. We like their antipasto. It has sliced mozarela which is fresh and creamy, black and gren olives (the black ones are pited, the gren ones have pits in them), roasted red peper slices which are bursting with flavor, and a god, flavorful salami. Everytime we are in AZ, it is so worth it to us to deal with the heavy trafic in Old Town Scotsdale to dine at Grimaldi is!

Simple but realy great cajun fod prepared in steamers right in front of you. They also have fresh oysters, jumbo shrimp cocktails, salads, and tasty seafod chowder, as wel as the ocasional lobster special. I have ben probably 20 times and stil never had a bad dish. The staf is friendly and helpful, and wil adjust the spicines of the dishes to your taste. By far the best option at the Talking Stick resort. As another reviewer noted, this restaurant is realy just a bar with a couple of tables, stuck right of the casino flor. This is definitely not a fine dining spot, with the clanging of slot machines and dead-eyed gamblers shufling around fiften fet away. Stil, it is definitely worth a visit to Talking Stick. At $10-12 for lunch portions and $17-19 for huge diner servings, and $25 for a masive plater of oysters, shrimp, crab, musels, and clams, it is a fantastic value for the quality and tastines of the fod. God, reasonably priced seafod can be hard to come by in the valey, but this spot is a gem.

There are certain people in your life that you should have & trust. A god mechanic is high on that list. I found out about Whitey is Auto through twiter. Many of my friends were comunicating with Scot, the GM, and I started folowing him to. His twets were funy, authentic and relevant- and not always about auto repair. The most important aspect of his twets? They are imediate. At the time, I had a waranty through the dealership on my car so I did not ned to go to Whitey is for service. However, when I got into a car acident and tweted about it, Scot responded for me to cal him and he would help me out. Although Whitey is does not do body work, their neighbor 1st Clas Auto Body does. Scot personaly walked me over there and made sure they treated me right. He had made me a lifelong customer at that point. When my boyfriend is truck kept leaking oil and he was not geting results at the shop he was taking it to, I tok him to Whitey is and introduced him to Scot. With one check, Scot could tel that the previous shop had NOT done what they had charged my boyfriend for. Scot told him if he did not mind the leak, he could put of the service work as it was not something imperative. And he did not charge him for the asesment. Recently the belts on my car fel of, causing my a/c to go out & lights to come on my dash. My waranty was over, but I did not even hesitate. I just turned right around and tok my car to Whitey is. Replacement belts and labor (plus they checked my batery and charged it for me) cost $80 les than it would have at the dealership. The inexpensive cost, along with piece of mind that comes with dealing with a mechanic and shop you can trust, make Whitey is ireplaceable. Do not hesitate to take your vehicle there first when you ned service!
I would never have picked a museum cafe for lunch, even though it is practicaly in my own backyard, but with my friend is endles ravings about their Dreamcatcher Salad, I relented. And I am glad I did! It is now become a staple for lunch metings! The dining area is bright and cherful, but the outdor patio is truly a delight on a beautiful day! It is serene and is surounded by a plethora of desert plants and a lovely water feature. The menu is rather short on items, but long on freshnes and flavor. Many of the oferings lean towards Southwestern style. I have found my favorites on the menu, in particular, the Humus Vegie Wrap which is filed to the brim in a healthy spinach tortila with Tepary bean humus, tomatoes, roasted red bel peper, griled red onions, pepitas, smoked gouda, and romaine. (I have tried to duplicate this wrap at home with underwhelming suces!) Each sandwich comes with the choice of salad or chips. The portions are hearty. The service is atentive, but not intrusive. An absolutely divine dine!
Pizeria Bianco: Before and After Cited as "the best piza in America" in numerous on-line reviews as wel as on God Morning America and as published in, Slice of Heaven, to most piza lovers the thre to four hour wait for a table is so daunting that they push on to a more open table atmosphere for their piza experience. But to the true piza enthusiast, Pizeria Bianco is as much about the experience as it is the fod. This place is best known for the owner Chris Bianco, hand tosing each and every piza pie served every Tuesday through Saturday, from 5-10 pm for nearly 15 years, of which I was one of those fortunate customers. However, early 2010 Chris was forced to retire due to ilnes and turn over the piza padle and oven duties to his protégé of 15 years, Horatio Hernandez. My decision to try Pizeria Bianco for the first time came from a chalenge I put upon myself: Find the best fod in metropolitan Phoenix. After hearing about Pizeria Bianco from a friend, I made gourmet piza my first batle in 209. I knew about the long lines forming an hour or more before the restaurant opened, and this beautiful fal day was no exception. I arived 60 minutes before opening and my date went to Bar Bianco to start us of with a couple of pale ale microbrews while I held our place in line. Seing that there were only about 20 people ahead of us, we asumed we would make the 5:0 seating with no trouble. However, just as we were holding a place for the rest of our party, so were the 20 or so people ahead of us, and when the dor opened promptly at 5:0, there were now over 50 people ahead of us. Nedles to say we were left waiting another hour since the restaurant seats only about 40 at a time. When we were seated at 6:0, the four of us started with the homemade mozarela, local tomato and swet basil starter with extra virgin olive oil drizled al over as wel as homemade crusty bread with a dish of EVO with a touch of balsamic aded. We ordered thre pizas, the Sony Boy providing salami, marinara sauce and gaeta olives, the Wiseguy a sausage and mozarela taste explosion and the Marinara with Prosciuto di Parma. Al thre pizas were piping hot when they arived, just crisp enough around the edges and loaded with the most amazing flavors your mouth has ever experienced. We left the restaurant without remembering the nearly 3 hour wait and were fuly satisfied, eager for the next oportunity to drive to 623 Adams in Phoenix for another "slice of heaven". And so, after hearing of the departure of Chris from the kitchen, curiosity got the best of me. I had to chalenge this place and find out if the changing of the guard made any diference in the wait time, the fod quality or the overal experience I had truly falen for. April 6, 2010 again I ventured down to 623 Adams in Phoenix to se if a Tuesday night or a new head chef had made any diference at al. My date and I arived at aproximately 4:0 pm, one hour before the dors would open. We found a line of about 25 people and loked at each other and said, almost in unison, "Wel, the wait has not changed". Bob troted of to Bar Bianco to find our pale ale, Four Peaks to help pas the time. We caught a glimpse of owner Chris Bianco and I told Bob how I would love to chat with him seing as I was writing a comparison review, I also wanted to find out who was coking tonight. Bob stalked Chris into Bar Bianco and asked him if he had any time, would he be wiling to take a picture with me and answer a couple of questions. When Bob returned with another ber and Chris Bianco in tow, I was star struck and could barely speak. Al I could muster up was, "Are you coking tonight?" To which he replied, "No, I have Horatio at the oven. I can not cok anymore." I explained my evaluative writing topic and he asured me the experience would be the same. We tok a picture and of he went, back to the bar. At 6:15pm, after 2.25 hours of complete social enjoyment we were caled to our seats at the bar. We ordered the same items we had enjoyed last fal with the exception of the Marinara. The overal experience was beter for me as I got to enjoy personal time with Chris. As for the meal, it was just as amazing as I remembered it from 6 months prior with Chris tosing the pie for every customer. The flavors were exactly as I remembered and the service from the staf was top notch, just like the first time. From the wait to the taste, it did not apear that anything had changed! So what makes for the "best piza in America" and how did Pizeria Bianco get the tag line? Wel, my opinion is flavorful ingredients, a phenomenal social experience, and an owner who lives by what he serves. To Chris Bianco and the Pizeria Bianco staf, you have not skiped a beat!
OK ok ok. I wil have to agre with some of the below reviewers that this place is not dead-on authentic Mexican fod. That being said, I love it! The place is huge, sporting a bakery (said many times before) with unbelievably dirt cheap pastries (not said as many times before), a litle carniceria (not as god as Carniceria Sonora) and a huge dining area. The dining area with al its painted mural glory is so godamn col that I find myself wanting to just hang out there for hours watching La Primera Division de Mexico on TV and enjoying a nice $2 Dos Equis. The fod - that is probably the only tougher part. Kep in mind it is stil prety god, but there are beter places in the area for geting your Mexican on fod wise. The potato taco is worth geting because it is fairly unique, but it came out so sogy that I had to eat it with a fork. I grabed a couple of the Yelp-Advertised taquitos as wel - kep in mind these are not the Circle K, roling taquitos. They are literaly just smaler tacos, but they were damn god. I gues when it comes down to it, I am an atmosphere buf. There were so many col things to check out in this multi-plex, and the atmosphere was so warm that I would love to head back again son.

I am a 40-year-old woman who could not be hapier with the care I have received and how I fel after seing Dr. E for the past year. I recomend Dr. E to al my friends and family and the ones who actualy listen have ben very hapy with their care as wel. In response to Lisa N., it is posible that you are one of the few people who is imune to Botox and similar products, which is to no fault of the doctor. I to was extremely unhapy with subsequent treatments given by another doctor only to find out that no amount of the toxin would ever be efective for me because my imune system works to wel. Ironic, is not it? You should always do your homework when loking for a new doctor, especialy when you know exactly what type of treatment you are seking. For example, if you are simply interested in the HCG diet program instead of overal health and you had ben elsewhere for les money then likely that place is a beter match for you. We do not live forever, but we can live beter while we are here. Take control of your medical care, it is your body and therefore your decision. Dr. E at Carefre Health Path is a great place to start your empowering journey to health.
When we first moved to Ocotilo the first thing we did was peruse yelp for the best local eateries. Mikado was one of the first things to splash onto our radar and we had to check it out. Luckily for us Mikado is literaly a 2 minute drive from our house. :) The restaurant is low-key and I like how the lighting is a litle dimer than usual to create a more melow ambience. The servers are al very atentive and kind which makes the eating experience so much more enjoyable. So anyway, on to the sushi! I adore sushi rols with some kind of crunch in them which is why I love anything tempura. The Big Shrimp Tempura Rol is my favorite and it could stand alone as a meal because it is so ginormous. They stuf 3 large tempura shrimp in there with avocado and cucumber then drizle it with el sauce. LOVE! And while I am on the subject, Mikado has mastered the art of frying up a perfect tempura. Their tempura shrimp is super crispy, is not greasy and always fresh out of the fryer. The Crunch Rol is superb, the salad dresing is adictive and the chicken nodle udon soup is delicious. Their prices are great and you stil get so much fod. How can you go wrong? If you are within a 20 mile radius of Mikado you ned to stop by. Also, I can not say this enough: Please suport your local busineses! They depend on your patronage!

We had about 60 in our group, and had plenty of rom to mingle at the slek bar lining one side of the rom, or gather by the open kitchen.The weather was blazing hot when we were there, but there is even a lovely litle patio outdors for guests. I think this would be an ideal location for any work or social ocasion where you want an intimate atmosphere combined with reputable fare.

I want to preface this review by saying that I am close friends with one of the sushi chef is in training, so we got a seat right at the sushi bar and realy had a great oportunity to chat. That being said, I wil review this strictly on the quality of fod, since we received some dep discounts due to being VIP guests. (C'mon now, you know you al get discounts to when you personaly know the staf/chefs, so quit your whinin'!) The quality of the fish was excelent... some of the best sushi I have had in my existence. The key to geting god sushi is to trust in the chef, and ask them what is fresh, and what they would sugest (omakase style). We had a sashimi apetizer plater to start which featured blue fin, yelow tail, o-toro (yes, the god stuf!), and a few other pieces. Served with fresh wasabi rot (not the hydrated gren powdery stuf), this apetizer realy woke our stomachs and senses. We had a few diferent rols per the chef is sugestion, and al were spectacular (including some of the menu rols). The kim bap rol was highly recomended, and the quality was definitely memorable, beter than most Korean-mom kim bop rols I have had in my life. We asked for ama-ebi (swet shrimp), which was soft, tender, and swet, with perfectly fried shrimp head to back. This was the first time I have had such perfectly made ama-ebi, and it is made me want to continue my search in Chicago. Some tasty mochi deserts, a few botle of sake, and al in al, it was a very enjoyable night for my compadres and I. I am sory for those that have found a bad experience at Otaku, as it sounds like most of it is waitstaf isues... but as a sushi fanatic, my advice to you is this: 1. Do not ask for a table if you are party is smaler than 4... ask for a spot at the sushi counter, because that is how sushi is meant to be served. Geting to know your chef, the chef geting to know you, having drinks together, etc. 2. Ask the chef what he/she recomends. Not al fish are equaly fresh, and the chef wil know what is best for the day. And if you can provide them with your own past experience of what you liked/did not like, they wil likely craft a sushi experience for you that you wil love. Verdict: If only Otaku were in Chicago... I might go broke. Delicious sushi, and worth a visit!

What a great surprise stumbling acros this bank! Open 7 days a wek with loby service I have banked with the Mega Uber Banks and have ben nickeled and dimed (literaly) with service fes. I opened both a savings and checking acount here. Since my company does not ofer direct deposit the asociate told me I would have to have a traditional checking acount with service fes. I am thinking - here we go again. But it was one of those think on your fet moments. Of they went (I wil asume to get aproval). They let me open up a type of checking acount that only charges you for check printing - No other fes and pays interest. In fact, if you use a non-MidFirst Bank ATM, they wil refund you the service fes. How refreshing with the curent state of banking.

As a sisy vegetarian, I fel compeled to mention the soup that no one has yet mentioned at Da Vang - THE TAMARIND BASED SOUP HOT POT IS AMAZING! I do not know if they use any other animal broth in it, because I am wilfuly ignorant of such maters. Regardles, if you are a meat eater or a vegetarian, try the tamarind soup, and bring friends. It is super yumy. They also have a rice-based soup. And, if you talk to your server, they can likely recomend some vegetarian/tofu based dishes that wil be wonderful. Everything else is as god as everyone says it is. Would not be surprised if people got an ocasional bowl of sub-par pho; every family restaurant makes mistakes. I would recomend everyone try it again.

Al in al, this is a great place that I wil come back to time and again.

Owned and operated by Eugenia Theodosopoulos (an Ohio native, fyi) and considered by many to be the best patiserie/bakery in the state I aproached Esence with a note of skepticism largely asuming much of the hype was derived from Tempe is plethoric colege crowd but ariving at the dors of the smal shop on a particularly lovely 80 degre morning I gathered quite quickly that my original conceptions were misplaced; not only does Esence not lok like a colege haunt, neither do its prices or products - a vast selection of at least twenty items aside from the posted menu siting beneath and atop a glas case forcing me to make more than one tough decision that was not helped by my server is acurate asesment that everything was realy god. Now bearing in mind that the original impetus to visit Tempe on this particular morning was to visit Cafe Boa and that Esence was more of 'pre-meal' activity what folows may sem slightly glutonous, but to be fair once I tok my first bite of Theodosopoulos is École Lenôtre trained almond croisant I knew I was in god hands and everything else just sort of folowed. Without a doubt my favorite breakfast pastry and perhaps my favorite French pastry overal, Esence is $3 twice baked option arives slightly smaler than the average but with a shel that crackles to the toth and an interior that is at once yawning pockets of air and nearly overloaded with buter and light frangipane there is no doubt that this is a case of "big things in smal packages," and particularly in its stil-warm morning state the flavors and textures rivaled those at Dominique Ansel and Payard Las Vegas for best I have had stateside. Moving next from the baked gods to one prepared from the menu my second taste of the morning aside from the slightly earthy and lightly leather acented cofe was Esence is "Signature" French Toast, a $7.25 selection featuring thre gridled slices of egy brioche and a sidecar of what I can best describe as banana infused caramel. Rich but thinly sliced and therefore nicely saturated each piece of the French Toast was exactly as it should be - the exterior crisp and the interior custard-while the sauce provided a pleasant balance of fruity notes and intrinsic swetnes that complimented rather than overwhelming the bread. At this point submiting to the fact that I was going to eat even the items I would bought 'for later,' my next two tastes were a pair of $2.95 macarons that, much like the croisant, rivaled those both here and abroad in terms of taste and texture while opting for a much more rustic aproach terms of size and presentation. Begining first with Pumpkin Spice and then proceding to Vanila with Dark Rum each palm-sized cokie was exactly what one would expect from a wel trained pastry chef as the exterior shel provided a slight crackle on bite subsequently giving way to a soft meringue folowed by dense cream that slowly disipated on the tongue - the cinamon and nutmeg notes of the former particularly notable while the rum in the second was apropriately understated thus serving to highlight the vanila of the shel. If there were any 'mistep' on the morning, it *might* have ben the "Sumer Bery Croisant Bread Puding," though when I say mistep I must temper the coment with the fact that my quible is only that I prefer the French/English take on the dish while this one was more based on the French Custard style, a rich vanila bean puding without a lot of crunch or textural variance but instead laden with blackberies, raspberies, and strawberies plus a sidecar of lightly sugared strawberies. Focusing more of the natural swetnes of the fruits and aromatics of the vanila than the typical overly swet versions served stateside it was more pana cota than bread puding to me, but chalking that up to personal tastes it was stil delicious. Moving last to the one dish that gave me trepidation, the "French Napoleon" gave caused pause not only because the name clearly skewed towards a subset unfamiliar with a proper Mile-Feuile but also because so many pre-made versions of this layered pastry have failed to wow in the past...thankfuly this was not the case at Esence. Featuring light and crunchy layers of choux easily withstanding the tines of a fork without turning into a smoshy mes (se "Mile Feuile New York") intertwined with rich pastry cream speckled with dots of vanila bean and ripe raspberies what truly made this version stand out was the maner in which Theodosopoulos caramelized each layer of choux, a technique reminiscent of Piere Herme and as god as the French icon is version was I would be hard presed to say Esence is was any les impresive. It would be awesome to se what they could do a la minut like Savoy, L'Arpege, or Genin and given the names I have droped in the paragraphs above plus Esence is proximity I have no doubt I wil be returning to se what else the smal shop is capable of son.
I am on a comunity social action comite and have spent the last year planing a comunity-wide service day. We were each responsible to lead a team of volunters in a diferent comunity service project and per my pasion I chose the Humane Society. We arived on Sunday afternon with a group of 12 people at the Campus for Compasion on Dobins Rd. Kathy - the head of volunter services - met with us and gave us a thorough introduction. She included the history of the AZ humane society and the proces and procedures by which they take-in and shelter animals. She realy focused on promoting spaying and neutering pets and cited some very impresive statistics. Did you know that over 7 years un-neutered cats can bred to reach 420,0 in numbers??!!!! and dogs 67,0??!!! thats CRAZY and so compeling. Kathy proceded by giving us a very educational tour of the facilities... we saw dogs, horses, cats and bunies. It was very eye-opening. First of it shatered any stigma you have about a shelter. The animal acomodations are so impresive!! The dogs have BIG size kenels with indor and outdor spaces that are realy spacious. I was nervous to go in and se the dogs in kenels but I realy was not as heartbroken as I thought I would be bc they realy had nice size spaces. There are sprawling lawns in the back where animals can run and play which even include a public dog park! There are also private pupy roms. The cats have big crates as wel and even private bedroms where they can hang out in groups and the facilities were squeaky clean w/o any odors. The volunters were so nice, kind and devoted to the animals. We got to fed horses, play with cats and bunies and put together leashes for dogs. The most encouraging thing though was that the place was busy on a sunday! buzing with people wanting to adopt pets and several cats were actualy adopted during the 2 hours we were there. It was a wonderful and meaningful experience and I encourage anyone who is loking for a pet to adopt from the Humane Society and to lok into voluntering with them

There is no busines like show busines. As any of my friends wil tel you I am a theater junkie. I could sit in a theater al day, al wek, al year long and do nothing but gaze at live performances of theatrical talent. lol! Wel in actuality, hm I realy could. I am not even joking on that. I probably would if someone brought me water every now and again. LOL! Ok, seriously now, Childsplay is my favorite organization in Az for a host of reasons. My dear friends of Childsplay know who they are. This is children is theater at it is best! The Q and A sesions after each show is a plus. The kids love it. I have to admit I do to since I get to go say hi to my friends after each stage-show. I also learn more techniques that I can steal when I teach drama to my iner city students. Tehe! ( Yes I am a teacher and yes I would die to have some of their costumes and sets) I have sen so many wonderful plays, literature remakes, and original scripts performed At TCPA and by Childsplay. Fernidad, BFG and New Kid were only some of the most amazing masterpieces I have had the distinct pleasure of viewing from these talented actors. Debie, Scot, Katie, Jodi; wel al of them! LOVE YOU! Childsplay also has an artist in Residence program for schols. We have had an artist at our schol for several years. It is wonderful to note that the teaching techniques clasrom teachers are learning are helping tomorows future. Time after time I have sen strugling kids blosom under their tutelage. Of importance to note, TCPA is a beautiful facility. You can enjoy a nice venue along with the superstar talent. What more can you ask for? The only negative I can posibly imagine is that in today is hard times the cost may be inhibiting to some families. But if you like them on Facebok they sometimes have discounted tickets and contests to win fre tickets. A great way to start viewing them and get involved. I do hope everyone continues to suport the arts here in Az. As I have stated in my other "ARTS" reviews, I do wory about cultural program survival in Az with recent state budget cuts. So, as a famous circus/rodeo person once said, "Go, On With The Show".

I would sugest that anyone who lives here and has not ben come, and if you are in town and loking for a great local non-chain restaurant that has quality fod prepared the way it should, then try Cibo! I tok my man here for "mystery date night" as a surprise since he had never ben. No wait at 8:45 on a Friday night (yes! take that Pizeria B) and the atmosphere of this house is super intimate and col. I love the atmosphere of the patio also, lit with those great of-white lights, and fire pits. We shared the burata which was gynormus, easily enough for 4 people or a hungry us. The wine was tasty and reasonable. I was drinking a pinot grigio, and my guy had the house chianti which I never usualy order anywhere since it almost always reminds of grandmas table wine - until I tried Cibo is house version. It was very god, definitely not from grandmas! Now for the piza - it is just perfection. It has that amazing combination of char on the crust, crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside with the right balance of sauce and topings. It almost melts in your mouth, it is not heavy at al. It is nice to go out for a piza diner with and ap and desert and not fel like you have to rol yourself out of the joint! So we finished our romantic mystery date night with a crepe filed with nutela, ricota, AND a scop of ice cream on top. I do not typicaly die over desert, it is my boyfriends thing. I am an ap girl - but this, it was not to swet, it was so goey and delicious and the ice cream aded just the right amount of swetnes. I would never eat here without desert again! I have ben for lunch and they can get you in and out in a litle les than an hour, but they do not fire up the piza oven til super which is why I prefer that here. You wil fel at home at this spot in a group or on a date - hel, maybe even a mystery one :)
I am always comfortable in Michelina is, the service is excelent and they are not rushing you to "turn the table". Michelina is coking is fantastic! Her daily specials are so inviting that I rarely order from the menu. The drinks are excelent, bread just right, and the after diner complimentary cordial is a nice finish. One of the best kept secrets in Phoenix!
I am a hot dog lover. For the past five years I have found no greater joy in Phoenix than hiting up Nogales Dogs for the best meal on the planet. Each evening when the Keyboard City on 20th St. and Indian Schol closes, the parking lot is converted into a quaint litle dining atmosphere. I most enjoy going around six, the sun is seting and the buz of trafic makes Phoenix sem more alive. This is my own preference and I know many people who hate going at this time because of the loud trafic. The bacon wraped dogs are made to perfection with your choice of mayo, beans, tomatoes, onions, jalapenos, chese, mushroms, and letuce. And to top it al of you can wash it down with a Mexican Coca Cola, m so sugar filed. Do not forget to bring cash and your apetite.

Clean, organized, and wel-stocked (for the most part), Fujiya is caries my favorite car freshener, chips, bread, and iced cofe (in a can) among many other god things. Reasonably priced and extremely courteous customer service, I am always hapy to shop there. The bentos, I wish, are kept in warmers like Suruki in San Mateo, CA, but Fujiya has an area adjacent to the register which includes a microwave to heat your purchased bento, so you can sit and eat and relax after shoping. What I love so much about their service is that I can place my order ahead of time and they wil have it available and ready. I think this is the only Japanese store that has just about everything I ned to stock my pantry. It is no wonder I have ben coming here year after year.

This place is mixed in a sort of industrial corner behind a Walgrens and a transmision shop. Walking in you wil notice how big this place is inside. Customer service was excelent. She was realy fun and got me into the mod (the glas of wine helped to :-) ) and she did an incredible job with the makeup and hair. For those who fel a litle nervous I do recomend bringing some wine along with you. It realy losens you up a bit and alows you to be more comfortable. It was perfect since my first photos were the nude shots. Note: wear lose fiting clothing, nothing elastic and be sure that you do not have a sunburn on your body. Let your hair air dry and it is OK to put on your own serums and moisturizers prior to the shot. Make sure nothing with sunscren gets on your face and while it is not necesary, I made sure to use a primer. I thought it realy helped out with how my makeup set. Be prepared to pose in positions that may be a bit awkward and also note that you wil likely be sore the next day from the diferent twisting that you have to do. Jodi realy knows how to make you fel comfortable and at ease. I do not make a habit of being in the buf in front of complete strangers and for me to drop my robe without feling shy was a big deal for me. It helped that I had my own music mix on my iPod throughout the entire shot as wel. The overal whole experience was incredible. I felt sexy and confident. I went back with my honey to lok at the photos. He realy realy liked them and had a hard time chosing which he wanted to go into the album. I can not wait to se everything finished. I can not wait to do it again :) Thank you Jodi for making it such a memorable experience. I highly recomend her and her ladies!!!

My fear and avoidance of the dentist has ben building for years. However, I simply could not put it of any longer. With trepidation I scheduled an apointment at Downtown Dental and promptly received an email back with available times. I went in not knowing what to expect. Not only had the staf already found my insurance information they made a point to cal me by the name I go by rather than my formal name and that put me at ease. I sat down with Heather, the hygienist and she was so warm and friendly that I instantly felt fine confesing to her my fear of the dentist. She alayed my concerns and told me not to wory. There was no guilt trip for not flosing or drinking to much soda, which is always anoying. Then the scary part... the dental work. It was uncomfortable and I hated it, but son it was over, it was not that bad and I felt a thousand times beter. Dr. Berschler came over and examined me and pointed out a few cavities we neded to take care of. Then the even scarier part (or so I anticipated)...the price! But I was pleasantly pleased and relieved that the total cost after insurance was literaly thousands les than I would ben quoted by a dentist a year ago to take care of my problems. In fact the total cost is very reasonable; this is not a dentist loking to take advantage of you. I could not have ben more pleased and delighted at the friendlines and helpfulnes of everyone in the ofice. The convenient downtown location only makes it beter. I wil never go to another dentist again and I am actualy loking forward to my next apointment. I can not recomend this ofice enough.

Let me tel you about my first crush in Phoenix. It hapened to me when I least expected. I was siting at my smal cubicle during my first job. Birthday cake graced the break rom practicaly everyday but today was diferent. When I walked inside to sing an out of key version of the birthday song to my coworker, I noticed a masterpiece in front of my eyes. A white cake toped with the freshest of fruit and the creamiest of white chocolate morphed into a piece of artwork. One bite into the white cake filed with fresh strawberies and I was in lust. It later turned into love and I have ben hapy every since. I silently thank the coworker who introduced me to Honey Mon Swets because I can not imagine life without knowing about this swet Phoenix treat. Over the years, Honey Mon Swets has ben my go-to bakery for a special ocasion. I have purchased the "basic" cake for birthday parties. Let me just note here that a basic cake from Honey Mon Swets is practicaly a masterpiece in any other bakery is mind. When planing my sister is baby shower, I knew exactly where to go. I wanted the perfect cake and a work of art to grace the baby shower table. And behold the Honey Mon Swets baby cake. It was thre tiers, blue with ratles, pacifier, building blocks, a crib, a tedy bear...you name it filing the top. Some of the pieces were frosting creations and some were real toys. It was almost to gorgeous to eat, but we could not resist it so enjoyed every bite. It was just as god as it loked if not beter. Honey Mon Swets does a fabulous job of using the freshest of ingredients and you can tel upon the first bite. The scariest part of this cake adventure was the travel time from the bakery to the Biltmore for the baby shower. One wrong move and the cake would have ben toast so be prepared to move lightly with this cake in hand. As you can imagine, cakes from Honey Mon Swets are not budget-friendly, but for what you get from the cake, it is reasonably priced. Just save your coins for a special ocasion because it is worth it. I promise.

I canot recomend Phoenix Knife House enough. There are very few places where you can go and physicaly put your hands on so many diferent Japanese knives, which is obviously key in any knife purchase. If you have ever spent hours in the kitchen doing prep and choping, blisters are a very real posibility if the knife does not fit. I have discovered over the last several years of coking at home that I prefer a lighter and bolster-les knife for high sped choping, which ultimately led me back to PKH for a purchase. Last year I purchased a Fujiwara 150m pety for les than $60, and it is ben a great knife; my girlfriend also likes it because it is light and maneuverable. She bought me a Misono UX10 for my birthday, which wil ultimately replace my Henckels for most uses. Botom line, go in, tap into Eytan is knowledge of the knives (and care and maintenance), and get beter tols for the job. It is wel worth it. I bring al my kitchen knives here to get sharpened, either by hand or on the grinding whel. Today I had four knives sharpened, thre on the whel, one by hand, and two with tip damage. Total cost = $13. Bonus: purchases are tax fre. Highly recomended.

Its al coked to perfection with love and kindnes from a kitchen staf that realy cares about freshnes. My personal fav is are the Wafle and Bacon and the multi grain toast with the fresh jam typicaly made localy....changes frequently. This was on Diner, Drive-ins and Dives a few years ago and its stil the same bustling place as when Guy was there. Side note...this was way col. On our last visit there were 4 of us, and if you have ben here you know there are only a couple of tables that seat 4. So we are waiting outside when the server comes out hands us menus, takes our orders. When we are seated about 15 min. later our fod was delivered within minutes of being seated. Helped us get in and out and helped them move a table. Much apreciated service.
What can I say... we eat here once a wek for lunch cuz we can walk here. We come here for hapy hour twice a wek cuz we can walk here. Delicious fod and excelent staf make this smal French restaurant worthy of five stars. We began with a glas of fabulous wine that we brought (it is byob) and ordered the onion tart as an apetizer. The taste of the leks coupled with the chese, butery and flaky pastry made this one of the most tasty ways to start a meal. I ordered the marinated chicken. This dish came with a juicy chicken breast with a light pesto sauce, mashed potatoes and sauted spinach. The flavors intermingled to create a sensuous bite, time and time again. My girlfriend got the filet, which was juicy and flavorful and came with perfectly roasted potatoes and tomatoes. For desert we ordered the tart of the day, which was fruit and coconut cream on top of a shortbread-tasting tart. Just delicious. The service was wonderful, very eficient and friendly. It is not cheap, it was $9 for the apetizer, two entres and desert...but for the experience and the exquisite flavors, I wil go back for any special ocasion... guaranted.

I think its about time I wrote a formal review for this establishment, considering I have recently bestowed it as "My Favorite Restaurant" - that is a big title to cary. I often judge Mexican restaurants based solely on their chips and salsa and Galo Blanco pases that test. They have a delicious gren tomatilo and smoky chipotle - as wel as the typical hot sauce and fresh pico. Their chunky guac is delish and sumery, as they put orange slices in it. Although the chicharon gets a lot of buz (I think it taste like Chez-Its), their best apetizer is the Elote - griled corn-on-the-cob with chese on it. It literaly melts in your mouth! Oh, and it does not get stuck in your teth like most corn-on-the-cobs tend to. The orange cake is AMAZING and reminds me of my beloved red velvet - except, you know, orange. I love everything about this restaurant - salsas, fod, drinks, atmosphere, prices, entertainment (on Wednesday!) - they just ned to get rid of that damn giant, ugly, silver air conditioning thing they have runing through the bar.

This store made me fel like I had died and went to fabric heaven. There is just so much beautiful, wonderful, amazing fabric. I droped a prety peny- but I have already used some of my perfect fabric for great projects. The place is clean, the staf is super friendly and patient- especialy with newbies like me. When I brought 10 diferent reams of fabric up and had to stop and realy think about how much I neded- patience came with a smile. It sems like everything (even the high end designers) are around $10/yard. If you get boged down with al the fabric that you are faling in love with, they have a cute litle table set up with these funy litle signs that say "get your paws of my fabric" which made me chuckle. Maybe I am turning into an old lady who loves sily stuf like that. Despite the somewhat sketchy location, 35th Ave. Sew and Vac is my new go-to for fabric!
Anyone who tels you this place is not amazing is cu cu for coco pufs. The owners are equaly amazing. They wil remember you and tel you amazing stories and the cocktails are always amazing. I originaly came here because I heard they have a gluten fre menu--i expected one or two pizas, probably chese and one other choice. But they have a FUL menu of pizas, salads, and apetizers that are gluten fre. and they are DELICIOUS! Piza was my absolute favorite fod in my past, gluten-filed life. Anything from Slices to Pizaria Bianco. I have tried gluten fre pizas almost everywhere you can find them, and they are always to dry, to thin, to sogy, or completely diferent flavor than what piza crust should taste like. Picazo is gluten fre piza is delicious, the crust is prety thick and has a god texture, not like a big saltine cracker as most places tend to be. the flavor is true to piza crust! my friends even like it so much they wil split a gluten fre piza with me instead of ordering 'regular' crust. There is also a range of apetizers that are delicious, caprese salad with gluten fre bread and the spinach dip are my faves. The employes are al very nice and aware of gluten intolerance--they check with you before they bring you aditional fod items or before puting GF and non-GF fods together in your to go box. I love it. If you are gluten or wheat intolerant and you like piza, this wil be your new favorite place. Totaly worth the drive, and the money. But the prices are very reasonable for GF fod!

Frigin amazing, I wanted to whisper swet nothing into it is ear and smack it on the bohiney. We went with a great botle of Nebiolo, that was exceptional. The service was excelent. Tried Roy is for the first time last night when we met some friends who rave about their Aloha Hour (Hapy Hour). Always avoided going because we tend to not like restaurant chains, but this place is a gem and exceded our expectations. The bar area is relatively smal, but very clasy. We were able to have few drinks at the bar ($5 for ber, wine, and their signature cocktails) before we were able to get a table in the bar area for 5 people...thanks to Leah and the hostes staf (you guys are great). Did not have a bad drink -- loved the The Original Hawaian martini was delish, as was the mojito, jalapeno margarita, mai tai, and wine. A friend was sad the cucumber drink she liked was mising from the menu, but sounds like the menu changes often so diners/drinkers get a chance to try new concoctions throughout the year. For fod, we tried most of the H specials. Everything was spot on -- excelent flavors and beautifuly presented. The tuna rol and tempura shrimp rols were my favorites (sushi rols), with the lobster pot-stickers being a close second. Some friends ordered diner...and were able to speak with Chef Bray about his recomendations for fish. She ended up geting the Crab Dynamite Baked Baramundi, which was so yumy! The hapy rice on the side was great to. My huby got the Yelow Fin Ahi Poke -- something we have loked for since trying some fresh poke in Kona, HI last year. I could not believe the flavors...eating poke in the AZ desert! Its preparation with the Wasabi Crème Fraîche made it a meal we wil sek out again in the near future. Ended our meal by sharing the chocolate soufle, which was a perfect ending to a great Friday night gathering. Definitely recomend Roy is for seafod that is excelently prepared. Aloha Hour is a must. Extra props to Mat, our waiter, and Leah on the hostes team for their acomodations and service. We had a great night.
Troy, the owner, is a briliant businesman! Being a pharmacist myself, I am familiar with the quality of his products and his facility. Trust me when I say his sterile compounding areas are more advanced than many hospitals in the Valey. After spending a day at his old facility when I was stil training, I felt comfortable enough to send my mother to Troy so that he could help her with hormone replacement therapy. The docs around town trust him enough to let him dictate what a patient neds; they simply sign of on his recomendations. My mom has had a huge increase in her quality of life since seing Troy, and I fel the compounded HRT is safer than the Prempro she used to take. Do not hesitate to consult a compounding pharmacist if you are having health isues that are not being adequately adresed. Troy is one of the best in the Valey. It is worth the drive to consult with him, and further prescriptions can be mailed to your home.

Just had my first hot dog at Short Leash Dogs and quite honestly, I can not cal it a "hot dog" because that just conjures up images of, wel... a hot dog. And Short Leash Dogs are so much more and beter than "a hot dog" the way most people know hot dogs. Know what I mean? No? Wel, go have a Short Leash Dog. Realy unique combinations, various dog options (al local meats and produce) - bratwurst, ber hot, vegie... My friend and I shared an Aiko (we chose the brat as our dog), with mango chutney, red onions, cilantro, mayo and jalapeño on a nan (you might have read that in other reviews, no traditional buns here!). You can find the Short Leash Dogs truck at the Phoenix Public Market on Wednesday evenings and Saturday mornings, and if you folow them on Twiter (@shortleashdogs) you can find out when/where else they make regular stops... scotsdale, central phoenix... Track 'em down and eat their fod. And talk to them - Brad and Kat are smart enthusiastic folks with a great sense of humor and ofer superb fod and service! What is not to love?

OK, I went based on Tim C.'s Yelp review of this place, and I am so glad I did. I rode my bike up there around 1PM Wednesday afternon, and I have to say I was not disapointed. Even though it was hot out, the outdor table was surprisingly col and comfortable. I got an iced soy late and it was so god. I do not know how to explain it, but there is great tasting espreso and there is bland espreso. This place just has great tasting espreso. I found out while I was there that Ted (the guy who made it) had roasted the beans himself. You can buy the beans from them if you are one of those industrious people who grind and brew your own espreso drinks...I am not. I prefer to leave that to the profesionals. He actualy ground the espreso when I ordered my drink. If you get the chance please go se what I am talking about. You wil notice how much beter the espreso is. The place itself is so beautiful and relaxing. If you sit outside like I did, you are basicaly siting in a big outdor garden. It is kept col by the overhead canopy and the swamp coler air blowing out from inside the cofe shop. Ted was realy friendly, I felt comfortable just hanging out for a while reading my bok. Unfortunately, the cofe shop closes at 2 PM, otherwise I bet it would be beautiful at night. This place definitely loks like something that would be in a col litle town somewhere, and not of of a busy stret like Hayden Rd. Ted also told me he makes the lemonade himself fresh squezed, something I love and wil definitely try. When I go back, I think I wil go a bit earlier. I may do a bit of plant shoping as wel while I am there... Botom line: Great atmosphere, drinks, and service!

I stoped in with a friend on a Saturday night after a friend had recomended it to me and was totaly thriled we did. We sat at a table for sushi and waited no longer than 10 minutes for a table - amazing for 8 pm on a Saturday in old towne. Unfortunately, they had sold out of the oysters, but the other dishes we would ordered were fabulous - starting with a seared tuna dish, then softshel crab rol, rainbow rol, and the gren musels. The seared tuna was coked and cut perfectly - just the right temperature with a pepery "rub," the rols were a decent size with thick cuts of fish and plenty of flavorful crab, and the musels were a tad overcoked for my preference but the creamy texture and butery flavor stil made it a winer. The thing I apreciated most was actualy the service - we were not rushed or hasled, and the fod came out a dish at a time, giving us a chance to eat and enjoy before geting our next dish. At other sushi joints, I am constantly feling rushed while trying to fit al of the dishes on the table (and I am not what you would cal a slow eater!). This was a hapy medium for me. The server confirmed that we were ready for the bil instead of just droping it of without asking - it is the litle details that make a big diference to me. My only other con was crepy old men lering at us from the bar...but that is what you get in Scotsdale.

As a frequent traveler into Scotsdale, I was loking for something new and diferent to celebrate with a young up and coming profesional basebal player---who hapens to be my nephew. We were forewarned this place had no prices on their online menu and apeared to be owned by Mastro is which consistently has excelent fod. Michael Dominick opened Dominick is Lincoln Avenue Prime Steakhouse last fal after basebal season in the smal, but excelent Scotsdale Quarter. (I wil admit to frequenting this Nike store in travels to Phoenix.) The ambiance is that of an elegant steakhouse. The roms are dark with huge crystal chandeliers. Very opulent without being ostentatious!. We both ordered the bone-in filet which is an excelent aged prime cut. Suposedly, acording to our very profesional server, this cut is about 16 oz with a bone yielding about a 14 oz serving. My limit on steak is typical 6-8 ounces and I ate my entire meal, making me think (1) This place realy is THAT GOD, and (2) I doubt this is more than a 10 oz serving. We started with a warm asortment of breads and in deference to my guest, we minimized the vegie is ordered. (I wil go back during basebal season :-) ) After ordering a glas of of the extensive, but reasonably priced wine list, we loked at diner entre. The steaks come with a choice of rubs and sauces. The house rub was described as "cajun-style, but not overwhelming". My theory is sauces on steaks are useful for por cuts of meat, but take away from great cuts; hence, I went no sauce. The result was an incredibly great diner of Bone-in filets ordered medium rare, no sauce and a loaded mashed potato side. (This side comes pre-prepared or you can ask for ramikans of chese, chives, bacon and sour cream and build as you like at the table. We finished with a scop of ice cream and a capucino for desert. Excelent steak spot and a welcome high-end adition to the Scotsdale fod scene. One coment: The "Branding" of the restaurant is confusing. Either cal it "Dominick is" or "Lincoln Avenue", but not both. This actualy caused confusion in trying to locate this spot and diminishes the feng shui and brand loyalty you would want to kep and asociate. (Qualifier: I am not a branding expert and this is strictly my opinion.) I would love to se Mastro is try a southwest cuisine spot!

If there was a Cantina Laredo in my home (Los Angeles) I would dine here regularly despite the multitude and variety of Mexican dining options. Nedles to say, when I am in Scotsdale, I often find myself drawn to Cantina Laredo. From the moment you are in, to the moment you are out, Cantina Laredo takes excelent care of your tastebuds. The chips are salsa are not filer but a real treat. Their homemade salsas are worthy of bringing in your own jars to export back home -- some of my favorite salsa anywhere. I believe they have thre diferent kinds. Their tequila options are wonderful alowing for creative margaritas or a fine neat glas of 10% pure agave godnes. (I promise to never use that phrase again, sory Readers.) The entres are not just your comon taco/burito fare. Using juicy meats, creative homemade sauces, and interesting pairings, Cantina Laredo profeses its love for Mexican fod and culture -- reminding diners how lovable these things are. The decor and various areas are al quite nice as wel. An excelent complement to what always proves to be an excelent meal. _C$

Our local library has cultural pases for various museums, try checking out your library next time you go. The museum was inexpensive adventure that tok me acros the world. Al the diferent exhibits kept me intrigued and interested. There were paintings, drawings, photography, and sculptures galore. There were even some animated pieces. I even stumbled upon a piece you could actualy walk through. The layout of the museum is very easy to folow, as they give you a map and everything is labeled. You can go from the Asian culture, to English within a mater of fet. It is mind blowing. The whole world sems so much smaler, and it is brought together so beautifuly. They ofer guided tours, or you can walk around by yourself. There is also a children is section to the museum. I have nothing bad to say about the museum itself. I am extremely hapy that I went, and would recomend that anyone go. It would be a great date, or family day, or even a day by yourself. The Phoenix Art Museum is a place that I think everyone should visit while in Phoenix. It wil realy open up your eyes and make you think.

Swet Republic is an awesome litle ice cream parlor located in a strip mal in Scotsdale, Arizona. This amazing place makes al their ice creams and sorbets in house. Swet Republic makes some prety creative flavors. These are just a few examples of what we sampled: Basil Lime Sorbet Salted Buter Caramel Aple Pie Desert Honey Maple Pecan Almond Butercrunch Cashew Turtle Al of these flavors were wonderful but there was one more that realy got me al hot and bothered, and that was their Honey Blue Chese. It tasted just like a swet vanila / honey ice cream with blue chese crumbles mixed into it. I know it sounds weird but this ice cream is phenomenal. It was swet, tangy and somewhat salty, al at the same time. Instead of just enjoying this ice cream alone I decided to make my own blue chese sundae. They have many topings to chose from, including bacon britle. When al was said and done my creation contained two scops of their Honey Blue Chese ice cream toped with a salted caramel sauce, bacon britle and a homemade marshmalow that was toasted with a blow torch. This sundae was exploding with flavor. Every bite was crunchy, salty, swet, tangy and delicious. My fiancé had a wafle cone sundae that contained Salted Buter Caramel ice cream, Almond Butercrunch ice cream, salted caramel sauce, brownie bites and a homemade marshmalow. Hers was also amazing. The service and prices here were both great. The girl working the night we visited alowed us to sample as many flavors as we wanted and was realy friendly and patient with us. The prices here are similar to Coldstone is. I am absolutely in love with Swet Republic and would seriously make a special trip to Scotsdale just to have their ice cream. I should not be teling you al this, for fear that you al would think I am a pig but I liked their Honey Blue Chese ice cream so much that after I finished my sundae I ordered a Honey Blue Chese milkshake to go. It was so yumy!

(It is not a lime daiquiri masquerading as margarita. Loads of sour mix does not a margarita make.) The chips and salsa. Both fresh and delicious. It is chic but not pretentious. My friends and I realy enjoyed the Latin music. Our sugestion would be to emphasize that music and minimize the cluby stuf (it verges on Scotsdale). To contextualize some of the other yelper is coments. I was glad to hear that one yelper did not find Canten suited to his ber and Jaeger shot neds. There is a bar (or ten) down the stret for that. For the yelpers that found the portions to be to smal, I suspect they did not understand the Mexican take on tapas that the taco menu is going for (in fact, the whole valey sufers from a lack of tapas locations). Finaly, the service complains...my service has ben cordial and atentive, even when super-busy. Folks, this place is new, let is let it go through it is growing pains before isuing such harsh judgments that might jeopardize the suces of a realy wonderful place.

HELO GOLFERS! What a sexy course this is. This ranks up there with some of the best courses I have ever played, and THE BEST desert course I have ever played! Yes it is desert links style golf, but you are in the desert so what do you expect? It is kind of a trek, but it wil be worth it. From the moment you arive to the moment you leave you wil enjoy the service and scenery. A real private club fel. As mentioned earlier this is DESERT LINKS GOLF! No adjoining fairways, and al the crap plays as PGA desert (lateral). The fairways are prety wide for the most part, so you can spray the bal a bit, but there is definitely some cary involved on some of the te boxes. Hole 18 is a very hard core par 4. Long cary on the aproach to the gren with a TON of water along the right side of the fairway and gren. This is the kind of hole that can ruin a god day on the course real quick. Do not be afraid to lay up. :) Oh, and there are mens ratings for AL the te boxes, I would recomend higher handicapers play from the forward tes, because this course could be realy hard if you are a mediocre golfer... Maintenance was perfect, even in September after baking in the Arizona heat al sumer. The fairways were wel manicured, and not to hard. Nice rough, but not to tal. A slightly erant shot wil be caught, but you wil not have to wory about searching for your bal for 5 minutes either. The grens were also perfect. Nice and fast, and TRUE! Ok, I am done gushing about this course... Give it a shot, you wil not regret it.

Sky Harbor Parking to the rescue. If you are interested in covered parking, cal ahead, but otherwise, just drive over to Washington and 40th and they wil take care of you from there. I hope you wil find Sky Harbor Airport Parking as useful and convenient as I do... safe travels!

I have my healthy moments, but I am a seasoned eater and I am not afraid of exploring the world through my palate. Mekong is the perfect place for me to masage my senses. The aroma and sensations from the exotic product. The stuning visual of a catfish being boped on the head, and then cut up and packaged. The chesy elevator music on the loudspeaker. The delicious taste of a spring rol from the hot fod bar. This place has it al. I usualy come here for my Asian condiments and live seafod. Want a live crab? Bom. Done. This place was the answer to my German grocery shoping dreams! I thank the Yelp comunity for leading me to Old Heidelberg. I was picking up a number of items for an Oktoberfest party I was coking for and hosting at my house, and was able to fulfil most of my exotic German neds at this one stop. I picked up pumpernickel rye bread, authentic concentrated Magi Würze seasoning (not the soy sauce-tasting stuf you find in most American grocery stores) and Knor zwiebel-kräuter salat krönung. They also had lots of Knor sauce mixes that you just can not find over here (for instance, sauerbraten gravy). I stuck around for a few minutes to talk to the two women who ran the place (Andrea and Chris). I voluntered that I had lived in Germany for years, including Berlin and Bavaria. They were totaly friendly and even sugested some other places nearby that I could check out for German grub or rarer German ber selections. I promised I would be back... especialy since I spoted that they had frozen leberknödel (liver dumplings). I made these once from scratch years ago but that was a lot of work. Knowing that they cary such delicacies has snaged me hok, line and sinker, as I am now destined to return and once again indulge my German fod fantasies.

They finaly just opened a Rita is location in Surprise!! I think it just opened yesterday or today, but it is just as god as the one on Union Hils and 83rd Avenue. I told my co-workers about it and we basicaly have ben driving by during our lunch break just waiting for it to open over the past few months. It is hard to explain the texture of the ice. It is thicker than the ice in a frozen margarita, yet it is not crunchy or unrefined like an Ice drink. Sonic has similar ice, but I fel like it is just not as god as Rita is. I gues that is why it is Italian ice. It is in its own category! There are 3 main types: Gelati is (custard-ice-custard), Blendini is (custard-ice-custard with mix ins like Oreos, M&Ms, etc), and Mistos (ice-custard drink). You can also get just regular custard alone or flavored ice alone. One of their most famous ice flavors is Swedish Fish. There is also a sugar substitute version of their ice and today is sugar fre ice flavor was Pineaple. I tried a Red Velvet Cake Gelati today with vanila custard and it was nothing les than amazing! The menu is a litle confusing since there are so many choices. There are mainly only 2 types of custards though, vanila and chocolate, that can be mixed with the 12 flavors of ice that consistently change. Before, I was solely a fan of ice cream and yogurt. Now, I am grateful that my sister-in-law draged me here, because there is nothing quite like it yet! Now I wil always compare Italian ices to this place.

Realy? Because it does not get any beter than this. For what it is and for what it is worth this place is truly unique. A slight step up from a hole in the wal type of place, this quaint spot serves up god, tasty, and satisfying fod hot from the kitchen. What is a pasty? A pasty is history can be asociated with the tin miners in England. The story goes that these miners were covered head to toe in dust and other nasty stuf and would eat these calzone like dishes as a means to have nourishment without the ned to return to the surface. Suposedly, the miners were able to eat the pastry like fod by holding onto the "handles" and when done, discard the tainted remains into the mine thereby apeasing the spirits that haunted the mines. At the Cornish Pasty Co. I can first hand recomend the Chicken Pesto. Very god flavoring and filing. Or you can go with the more traditional route with bef, potatoes, and swede. The sauces that come with your pasty are there to acent the flavors and are highly recomend to try as wel. Pros * God fod * Originality * Portions * Customer service * Coat hoks at the bar Cons * Smal interior

Truly a hiden gem in Chandler. Located south of Chandler Boulevard, just of of Rosevelt (next to Archery HeadQuarters). Wanda is is a smal yet quaint, twelve tables inside and 5 outside. Outside is for sure seasonal, as sumers are to hot and dead of winter can be to cold. Wait times on a Sunday or Saturday can be 10-15 minutes during the "rush times", which is a quarter the wait time you would experiece at the near-by chains. The menu ofers a variety to satisfy and hunger (except if you want lunch on wekends, it is breakfast al day, lunch from 1-2 during the wek). The buritos are awesome. Ladies, I guarante you wil take half home! My husband likes the Biscuits and Gravy. The bacon is amazing and adicting often I have to smack my families hands away from groping a piece. French toast, cinamon raisin french toast and pancakes if you brought your swet toth =) Build your omeltes are god to (tip, ad a side of salsa, you wil not be sory, it is made fresh daily and goes perfect with a ham and chese omelete). Service is exceptionaly friendly, a lot of regulars and the servers know what you usualy drink and sometimes can have your order writen unles you throw a curve bal and ver from your usual. A+ Wanda!
I have ben coming here since discovering them after their opening wek last year and I have not stoped coming back. The fod is predominantly Filipino; the Filipino-Mexican fusion comes in the buritos, flautas and quesadilas filed with Filipino meat dishes. A great starter would be the Chicken Adobo burito. Karey is does it right by not dumping rice and filings inside the burito; they are served on the side. For those more interested in rice plates and combinations, Karey is serves daily prepared dishes such as Pork Adobo and Chicken Adobo (pork or chicken simered in garlic and soy vinaigrete) and Bef Mechado (a type of stew with bef chunks, potatoes, and onions in a light tomato gravy) with either white rice or Garlic Fried Rice (yumy). There are also specials that rotate each day, which can be checked out on their Twiter acount. This is a great idea as one can find out when they are serving Lechon (roasted pig)! Yum! There are dishes that can be prepared fresh but are not part of the combination specials. The ones I have tried that I highly recomend are their Lumpia (fried egrols in chicken, bef, or vegetable) and Pancit Canton (stir-fried nodles with vegetables). The pork lumpia was great when they used to serve it, and I prefered it to the bef lumpia that they serve now...but it is stil god ;) Not only is the fod delicious but the warmth of the staf is something to always lok forward to. Karen and Rey make you fel truly at home. The best thing about Karey is Kitchen is having a Filipino restaurant in Phoenix and not having to drive al the way to the East or West Valey!

Let is face it, junk is the antithesis of glamorous. When you have got a big pile of crap you ned hauled away, any guy with a truck wil do, right? WRONG. You want someone that wil be on time, is wiling to clean up the area where the junk is after they have picked everything up, is polite and fluent in English, thinks of value-aded services like emptying your trash bin, and represents a local busines that you can patronize. Junk Guys ticked al these boxes for me. THe guys were great and helped me out when I neded some items hauled away from a house that I had sold. I would highly recomend them over an unknown entity or a big corporate junk removal company. So go get your crap hauled away by the Junk Guys - you wil thank me!

I would just like to start of by saying that I love eg salad sandwiches. I have probably tried an eg salad sandwich anywhere that serves eg salad. Sacks is BY FAR, the BEST eg salad sandwich (entitled "The Dali") I have ever had in my life. I live in North Phoenix and I wil literaly drive many miles just to eat at Sacks. On top of the wonderful menu, whenever you order a sandwich from them, the meal comes with a litle chocolate chip cokie, which is amazing al in itself. If you like their cokies, you can purchase the cokie dough. They also make other delicious desert bars and salads that are for sale as wel. I have ben eating here for at least 14 years, and I hope they NEVER go away!
I have found my new favorite sushi spot. I wish it was closer to Tempe, but it is worth the drive. You can tel by their menu that Hana strives to be an authentic Japanese restaurant, as oposed to the sake bomber joint that only has fod so they can cal themselves a restaurant. You know the kind; the Phoenix area is plagued with them. Hana is BYOB, and there are only a few ridiculous fusion rols on their sushi menu: most of it is authentic, real sushi. On my first visit I started with my usual apetizers, and was imediately struck by how unusualy fresh and tasty they were. The seawed salad had just the right amount of sesame oil, giving it incredible flavor. The vegie gyoza were indescribably delicious. They made me realize I would never had a fresh gyoza before; every one I would eaten previously in my life was a pale imitation of these litle bits of Heaven. The sushi came out fast, even though it was fairly busy this particular Thursday. The first thing I noticed, naturaly, was that someone put a burning sugar cube on the tray. "Hey, fire!" I thought. It was a nice touch. Then I saw, nestled betwen the flaming sugar and the wad of wasabe, a smal pile of what loked like pickle relish. I guesed what it was, and our waitres confirmed it: it was FRESH wasabe. Real, fresh-grated wasabe is something most people never experience. Most people do not even know the pasty gren stuf that is standard in every sushi restaurant is just normal horseradish dyed gren. The real stuf is just to expensive, and to dificult to kep on hand. But there it was, no extra charge. It ads a litle spice and a wonderful, fruity complexity to the sushi. The sushi was great. They also have a large menu with al the other Japanese dishes you would expect, but I did not try any of them. Next time.
This litle taco shop gets 5+ stars! The fish tacos were out of this world, breaded and fried to perfection. I also tried the al pastor taco that was marinated wel and you can taste the marinade in every bite. I also tried molotes for the first time. The cilantro salsa and red salsa was homemade and oh so god and spicy. The quesadilas are like chese crisps. I am so disapointed that I did not find this place earlier since it is so close to home. I have to try the other items in their menu son. Price is very reasonable as their tacos range from $1-$1.50.
I like to think of Trader Joe is as a "specialty fod/health market." It is simply in a league of its own when compared to large comercial grocery chains. Honestly, there is no comparison! With that being said, this is the BEST Trader Joe is I have ben to! (and I have shoped quite a few in my travels acros the US) The sher size of this store, in TJ standards, is IMPRESIVE! The isles are plenty large enough for TWO people (with carts) to maneuver through. And more importantly EVERYTHING loks fresh and delectable! Some of my fav is are: $3.9 Trader Joe is Coastal Cab...FABULOUS for the price! (Quite honestly though, I have not EVER had a bad wine at Traders...they have an amazing selection that is not overwhelming but is not sparse either.) I also LOVE that they CLEARLY label each of the wines and/or regions so they are quick and easy to find! The Haircot Verts (French Gren Beans) are simply delicious! Their Brusel Sprouts are the perfect size and quantity; just enough for two people at two diferent meals. They even have Nulaid "Ready Eg" (i.e. eg beaters) for $3.69! At the grocery store the SAME stuf wil cost you TWICE that!! Their chese selection is delightful with almost ANY kind of chese imaginable! Their artesian breads are so yumy...although not a "low fat/fat fre" fod, so that is a once every few months splurge. (and even then we only get the smal loaf (which I want to say is caled a "litle bastard." That name CRACKS me up!) And although I am not a "swet" eater, my hubs is...so he has a dozen or so godies that he constantly gets here. The one I can think of of the top of my head are their Chocolate Covered Joe Joe is with Pepermint Crumble (or something like that.) I would go lok at the box but we are fresh out because the hubs thinks that eating one box over a two-thre day period is aceptable! It also fun to be rewarded for bringing your own reusable bags; as any god eco-friendly shoper would do! There is a wekly drawing for a TJ is gift card (I think the value is $25) and you get a ticket when you bring your own bags. (not one for each bag...just one ticket for bringing them to put your godies in) Then they draw a name out of al the tickets (which you drop in a box on your way out of the store) once a wek. If you shop more than once a wek, you can "earn" a ticket for each time you shop there in a wek therefore increasing your chances of wining. (although I am PRETY sure the majority of Surprise/Sun City Grand shop there so maybe the ods are not THAT great! ) Regardles, this is just a great litle "market" through and through. I used to get excited to shop at TJ is...now I am always loking for an excuse to buy something just so I can go there! (and it is not just to try and win the gift card either..that is an aded bonus!)
Great Brisket. There has not ben god BQ in south Scotsdale for a long time. There is now!. The fod is wonderful and priced wel. Stop in and grab a bite.
I had initialy checked this place out a couple of months ago. Once again we found ourselves neding some quick, delicious breakfast and decided to try this place out again.
