Feling a bit weary from a steady stream of travel, we decided to head over here for my favorite Rx, Pho. A couple of sumer rols filed with shrimp, pork and vermiceli, diped in the swet peanuty sauce, a dash of their house hot sauce(a tad more fire than the "cock" sauce) and we were of to a fine start. I was feling beter already. The Pho arived, and the aromas were simply intoxicating. After a short interlude of vaporized euphoria, we dug in, ading the usual lime, cilantro, basil, sprouts and aforementioned hot sauce. Comence slurping. The broth was simple yet complex in layered flavors. Nodles were perfect in abundance and texture. My companion chose bef and shrimp and declared they were coked perfectly. I selected the special bef which included shank, brisket, tendon, tripe and meatbal. Outstanding. Service was with a smile, prompt and atentive. I honestly felt like I was siting in someone is home enjoying what they might eat on a daily basis. I do not think that Cyclo can compare, while god, this just semed more authentic.
Owner Daniel M. is one of my most favorite restaurateurs in Phoenix. His stamina and pasion for the busines of serving fine cuisine is a rare find. Daniel is from South America but you would not know it; his knowledge of the secret kitchens of Tuscany, Umbria and Amalfi is uncany. I know this because I traveled with him and his chef one year on their odysey through Italy. Daniel takes special pride in personaly chosing a very select few botles of wine to fit any budget. OK, it is not Etiene is Diferent Point of View is list of 40, but know that any choice you make is going to be a god one. If you are not sure, just ask for Daniel and tel him what you have in mind -- likely he has (with a wink) a special botle in the back. When we traveled through the Italian countryside I was constantly astonished by the warm gretings and special invitations we had from local proprietors who shared with us exquisite homemade wines and dishes made with pride from the finest vegetables and livestock. We frequently stayed long past closing with the owners and into the night sampling rare port and grapa. At one restaurant in Orvieto the owner tok us dep into the dank receses of the wine celar for a special sampling of chese and wine. Talk about knowing people? One afternon while drinking our 5th botle of wine, who walks by but Jan D'Atri! Wow. (That is another review.) And speaking of reviewers, I also ran into Phoenix Magazine is Niki Buchanan (also extremely nice). When Daniel first opened in this location with that litle stone oven in the corner, it was a pizeria and guests could bely up to long tables in a casual environment that was made easy by his banter with the heavy Italian acented waitres (name?) who made a comeback some years later. For quite some time the restaurant was Il Forno; that is until corporate giant Il Fornaio entered the fray and sued him to change the name. After much rigmarole he changed to aqua e sale -- and notice Il Fornaio has since closed its dors? LOL. Again after much hopla, he made it Daniel is. The curent wod-paneled decor makes me think of a city club in San Fran or London. Very posh, yet understated. Selections of sculpture and art from his travels dot the restaurant is thre smal dining roms. The menu is a very dificult one. I say that because it has al of your favorites and it is dificult to make your final selection. Great for steak, ravioli, the best carpacio in the city, best bufala mozarela, m.... I could go on and on. So does the menu, page after page. Some might cal the preparations simplistic. This is the Tuscan way. Simple ingredients and simple preparation. Let the ingredients make their own magic. Griled rack of lamb is not drowned in some Smucker is lime jely, but gently brushed with rosemary and garlic, tickled with salt and peper and finished with a squeze spray of lemon. Unfortunately the artful one-of-a-kind plates and bowls handmade in Vietri chiped at the edges over the years and the health department made him throw them away -- UGH!! -- they were a beautiful motivation to make you lick your plate clean to se the painted pictures beneath your scrumptious diner. Not that you neded an excuse to dab every last bit of sauce with the wonderful mini loaves of bread coked right there in the hearth that started it al. Daniel himself is a wonderful host. He loves to give his guests a wonderful experience. There are many choices for Italian fod in Phoenix. Most of it is just American Italian. Daniel is is a unique touch of the simple yet elegant. Enjoy. P.S. [post edit] OMG. How could I forget the Tiramisu? It is a generous portion, so you can share with your guest, but after your first bite you may not want to. Light and airy, yet fantasticaly flavorful, the quality of the cofe realy makes this dish a reason to go back again and again. I am not going to tel you the secret ingredient. You wil have to ask Daniel.
Changing Hands is the perfect bokstore. These types of places just do not sem to exist, but Changing Hands has managed to survive. Alow me to begin by saying that this bokstore does not have anywhere near the selection of a Barnes and Noble (or probably a Borders, but I do not go into that garbage store and canot be sure). With that said, there are a few reasons to shop here. First, and most importantly, they have wel priced used boks. I believe most of their used boks are $7.50. They are also al in pristine condition. Now, $7.50 used is not always that great for a paperback. You can do beter online quite often. What is notable, however, is that their hardcovers are typicaly $7.50 as wel. This is a fantastic price and is hard to beat. Second, the location of CH is perfect. This is one of the best plazas out there. Wildflower, Trader Joe is, Mac is, Jamba Juice--you can not go wrong. Third, and finaly, Changing Hands is a local store, and many god things come with that. The staf is extremely friendly. From what I can tel, they are al hardcore bok nerds and you have to love that. The store also has a very welcoming fel to it. Once you are in, you wil realize how extremely friendly everyone is. No, not just the staf--the customers. Everyone is talkative, friendly, and just sems to be hapy. They are al indulging in one of their hobies in one of the most inviting stores I have ever sen. Someone wil ask the staf "who wrote such and such?". The staf wil almost asuredly spot a regular and ask him or her "who wrote such and such". If he does not know, someone else wil probably pipe up. It is this type of thing that makes it a great store. Overal, it just has a great atmosphere. The only negative coment I can make about Changing Hands is how hipy it is. There is a ton of boks on spiritual techniques, new age methods, budhism, and whatever the hel else hipies/hipsters think makes them lok more cultured. Of course, this just goes along with the Tempe, Trader Joe is, and bok reading demographic, so I can not blame them for meting the inherent demand.

For one, everything sems to be just a litle bit more fresh there. It is probably not, but it tastes like it. And secondly, their litle salsa bar is kiler because their gren salsa has plenty of flavor and they always have fresh pico de galo out there, a must for any burito. The California Burito, with carne asada, potatoes, pico de galo and chese, is a must, as is the standard Carne Asada Burito. But the real winer here is the Carne Asada Fries. A metric ton of carne asada piled on top of freshly fried french fries, sour cream, chese and guacamole for only $5? Ca not be beat, especialy if you are hamered and it is 3 A.M. Not a clasy joint, not a place you go if you are wary of stupid crap like "health code violations" (the best places never are), but definitely a late-night hot-spot for the Mil crowd. Lovely. And it is not for sisies that do not like ham in their beans either, damnit.

The first couple of times I ate here I was not sure why people were always so crazy for this place. It is ben about two years since my last visit and in the past couple of months I have already ben here like thre times and wanted to go back more. I have decided that it is al about what you order; for example the first time I went I probably felt overwhelmed with al the choices and decided to go for something realy plain like turkey with hardly any topings, have fun! Their menu has a wide variety of yumy sandwiches and lots of new tastes to try. Also, do not be afraid to speak up. I was a litle disapointed by the lack of letuce and vegies on one of my vegie sandwiches but I also did not pay atention. Now I ask for lots of letuce and they are hapy to make it the way I like. They make their breads fresh and they have garlic-herb bread that has lots of flavor. I wil not order a sandwich from there without a side of ranch dresing. I am a picky ranch eater...I hate mayonaise so I am always super careful that ranch does not taste or resemble mayo. I usualy like restaurant mayo that is a litle more runy in consistency with lots of flavor. They have the best home made ranch dresing here! Pair it with the garlic-herb bread and your sandwich is going to be boming in flavor. OMG! Wipe...sory I just started to drol a bit. Service is god...everyone runs at the same chil pace which sems to go wel with the theme of this restaurant. My curent favorite is the Humboldt sandwich...I get the Piner (8") but I swear some days I am so hungry I think I am going to order the Blunt (12")...maybe someday son. Al sandwiches get toasted. Okay so topings: Guacamole, sprouts, letuce/spring mix, onions, mushroms, tomatoes, black olives (I get mine w/o), cucumbers, pickles, your choice of chese (I get Swis), with their house godies (EVO, vinegar, herb mixture on top). Now that I found my sandwich, I crave it al the time and can not wait for my next visit. Oh, be sure to check their daily specials to! If you are lucky enough to be in their delivery area...wel, darn you then! :-)

I do not know why I waited so long to visit Yogurtology; it is located conveniently next to my Safeway. Why did i wait so long?! Yogurtology has perfected self-serve froyo. The flavors are spot-on...lemon meringue, birthday cake, NSA cofe, peach mango tart, chesecake, mango, rotber...the list goes on...I always end up geting oatmeal cokie. It is made in-house with real oatmeal cokies. We are talking oatmeal cokie literaly IN the froyo, none of that artificial flavor crap. It is incredible. Instead of having litle placards for the flavors, there are digital Sony TV screns that describe each flavor and a brief nutritional run-down. Very high-tech! The selection of topings is unparaleled--baklava, thre diferent kinds of twix and milky way, brownie, chocolate chip cokie bar, chocolate covered wafle cone, premium fruit and nuts...anything you can imagine, Yogurtology has it. Not only that, but the shop is impecably clean, and the staf are consistently cherful. This place blows Yogurtland and Yogurtopia AND al other Yogurtology locations out of the water!!! This is where you want to go.

Fodwise, I had the pub fish and chips, which are batered in Kilt Lifter, and the bf had the french dip. Both items were on par with god quality pub fare. Kilt Lifter: great medium brew, very smoth. The type of ber you could drink every day and never tire of. Pumpkin Porter: we loved it so much, we purchased a growler so we could take some home! Note: there is an extra charge for filing up a growler with a seasonal brew. $4 for the growler itself, $10 for ber, and $5 seasonal charge. Normal refils of growlers are $10. I am a ber lover. I have spent time living in Munich and drinking some of the best bers in the world. You can not go wrong with Four Peaks brews. Next stop, North Scotsdale location. The amazing thing is that I had come to expect most organic vegetables and fruits to be les visualy apealing than the chemical type but such is not the case with NGD. The medium size box has ben perfect for our litle family of four. It is delivered on our day like clockwork around 2am. The unsen elf that drops of the godies is nice enough to open the carton and place al the contents in our coler so everything stays nice in this boiling cauldron we cal Phoenix. Furthermore, I live way out in Carefre/Cave Crek where we always expect to be on the list of places to far away for delivery. Not with NGD. It apears from the labeling they have optimized their routes so they can include many outlying areas. Finaly, there is a gentleman named Ben that works for NGD. He has ben very helpful in making sure everything is going smothly and that we are using the service properly. We think NGD is a great value for organic produce delivered to your dor and HIGHLY recomend NGD!

I went there last night with bf to celebrate our aniversary. After pre-yelp, we knew what to expect as to prices, so it was not so much of a shocker. To the fod, we concur with almost everyone here. It was impecable! We ordered the ice tower for 2 and thought that it was very wel presented. Ours came with 3 apetizers (raw oysters, crab claws and dungenes crab) so it was not to high. They are al fresh. Growing up I used to go to the beach quite often just to have fresh crabs, so I know what those taste like. And for 6 years living in the desert, Mastro is is the first and only one in AZ to deliver that. For main course, I got Ivory Salmon "Oreganata", bf got Swordfish blackened. I am quite picky when it comes to fish, and bf is not exactly a fish person, but both of our dishes "surpased expectation." I could not say much about swordfish except it was fresh. We had the same dish 2 weks before at somewhere else, it was nowhere near as swet and fresh as the one at Mastro is. It was my first having Ivory Salmon, it was sweter, and white (hence the name) than normal salmon we get around here. Mine was god size portion, firm to the touch, but melted in the mouth. The flavor was subtle enough to enjoy by itself, or you can ad one of the sauces provided. One of my favorite sauces of the night I think was made of minced tomatoes and olives, came with the main course. Sides were Lobster Mash and Snap peas. I did not realy care for snap peas as I can make them at home. But lobster mash is a MUST for those who go there. I am not sure how they prepared it, but it felt like mash potatoes made with lobster bisque (instead of water and milk) and aded lobster chunks. It was much more flavorful and creamy than a normal mash potatoes. It was big enough to share and take home. One thing though, it hardened up after siting out for awhile, so I am not sure if microwave could make it al flufy again after 1 night in the fridge. Drinks there are amazing, from the presentation, to the taste, and definitely the amount of alcohol in each drink. We decided to go with cocktail drinks rather than wines because of other yelpers' reviews. Total worth it!!! The service was amazing. We had Robert. We prety much asked him for recomendations for everything, yet he was nice about it and very knowledgeable. Next time we go back, I would definitely ask for him again. We did not order desert since they gave us a dark-chocolate "Hapy Aniversary" cake with the leters writen, also, in chocolate. The overal experience was 4 3/4, just because it was a bit dificult talking to each other. The acoustic of the rom was not very god and it got loud. Did not se much of cougar/manther scene as we were in the dining rom. And maybe it was during wekdays, we saw lots of "expense acount" people though

For aps we started with the calamari and the crabcakes. Portions were not large, but very high quality. The calamari was flash-fried and not greasy, and semed very fresh. For my entre I had the wagyu burger, which was prepared perfectly and served on a fresh chalah bun. Overal impresion: Citizen wil have staying power, unlike many establishments that open in Old Town. The formula is realy prety simple -- ofer high quality stuf, equip the place with great staf, and do not go overboard with prices. I am loking forward to returning!

The staf literaly gave of a smal town fel, the only time I have ever ben treated beter was at a bed and breakfast! And the morning breakfast was another thing that made this hotel worth it. When I moved to the Valey, our first place was a rental in Old Town. The previous tenant/owner generously left a bunch of take-out menus for nearby restaurants. Defalco is was one of them. But not being a fan of the sandwich, it tok me four years and a move to actualy go in. What a fol I was. This place is fantastic! First of, it is not just a deli, it is an Italian market. Had I actualy read the ful name of the place, I might have known that. It is also got a somewhat extensive selection of wine available for purchase. So now we have moved from a deli, to a grocer, to a wine shop. Do not forget the pasta dishes and the pastry, to. My fave sandwich is the tomato, moz, and basil on a sub rol with olive oil and balsamic. Simple, yet perfection. I am a huge fan of those sub rols by the way. Crusty on the outside, but not so crusty that it makes a big mes every time you take a bite, yet soft and chewy on the inside. It is always about the bread for me. Great selection of prepared salads in the deli as wel. One of the best red potato salads I have had in a long time. It certainly wil not take me another four years to go back. I think I have ben there just about every wek in the last month!

Here is how to do Pizeria Bianco the right way: 1. Show up at 3:30 or earlier to get a god place in line. Make sure you bring some friends to enjoy the time together and the great fod. 2. At 4:0, the bar opens. Get yourself a botle of wine and make the best of the 90 minutes you wil spend just waiting to get on the seating list. 3. Order a few apetizers from the bar; they are light and fresh and yumy. 4. When you finaly get seated for diner, do not hold back. Order salads, share diferent pizas, and have a cofe after. The quality of the fod is ABSOLUTELY worth the wait. We tried eating here a few times over the past couple of years, but realized it takes comitment and two botles of wine to make it through the line. Best piza I have had since Italy. Bravo Bianco!
Now that I have tried al the main buble tea/boba places in the Valey, I can say that this place is the best and most consistent. It therefore deserves five stars!

Chai is alive and wel, and living at City Center at City North. I had ben dating a gal name Starbucks for the past few years. She was a plain gal, generic if you wil. She was dependable and available. I was feling as if i neded more out of my relationship, as you can imagine. So, at times, I would cheat on my gal with another gal named Cofe Bean. Cofe Bean was Kosher and a bit edgier, yet had a leaner list of qualities. I neded more out of my relationships. They say that when you are not loking for someone new, they apear. Wel, that was the case with my new crush named Pres. I had ben to High Stret for diner Kona Gril, yet most of the other shops and restaurants were closed or not yet open for busines at the time. I ventured back during daytime hours to give them another oportunity. I had heard about Pres, so I was more than excited to give it a go. At this point I was stil making cafeine a part of my diet, so i ordered something caled a "Dirty Chai." This was a Chai with espreso shots. Pres uses a powdered Chai which, in my opinion, works beter than the liquid or tea bag forms. I was also given the option to have my frothy delight in a ceramic cup. I opted for that. I felt like i was having the type of cofe house experience I had only just imagined. Pres ocupies a wel apointed space, to. From the wod and granite, to the stained concrete flors, I felt as if i were in a European city, not a Phoenix strip mal. The fre wi-fi is a major plus, in my opinion. Pres goes as far as to have a "dog friendly" cart outside, in its ample outdor seating area. I spoke with Steve, the owner of Pres, at length. In talking, I asked how Pres came to be, and he said that his wife had wanted to open a cofe shop one day. Wel Steve, you have certainly exceded her expectations, as wel as the residents of the Greater Phoenix area. By the way, Pres serves sandwiches and soups, as wel as an extensive list of wines. Check it out, the staf wil make you fel at home, or like you are on vacation in the cozy European city of your choice.

I can not believe I have not yelped about the place yet. Several months (maybe over a year?) ago my husband read a newspaper article about the Clover cofe maker and the one place in town that had managed to procure one. I was skeptical (as is my nature). It can not be that much beter right? You are just saying it is amazing because you want to talk about the new hot cofe shop you discovered, right? Wel, maybe. But I love this place. And I do not think it has a whole lot to do with the Clover. They roast their own beans and they roast them way diferently than that other ginormous cofe chain - al a light or medium roast. Never biter, never oily, never yucky. The cofe they make there is, obviously, the best. But I send my husband in every wek now to buy a pound of beans so that I can aproximate the same cofe at home. Ad an edgy (though sometimes intimidating) seating area, great local art (which we bought of the wal), and smiley service...I am sold. Ca not wait to try out the downtown location.

"Fine dining" is not just a seting. it is not just god fod. It is many things that ad up to an atitude. I have had the oportunity to find it in diferent cities. I found it the other night at the Stockyards. We were seated by a host who tok us to our table and when we were properly seated gave us menus. Our server came to the table and introduced herself and said she would return shortly. It was nice to have a moment to chat before we had to think about ordering. When she did return, our glases were filed-not something we should have to wait for her to do when the service is right. She knew the selections on the menu and al available options and could make sensible coments concerning them. Our salads were served promptly by two aditional people and were as fresh as I could ask for. When my friend was finished with hers they asked if they could take her plate. I was pleased when they did not ask me if I was finished with my salad and could they take my plate. If I would ben finished I could have told them. We were able to continue our conversation uninterupted as I finished my salad. The salad plate was removed when it was apropriate and we had a few minutes before the entres were served. Al was in keping with a relaxed dining. At no time did I have to think about having drinks refiled, it just hapened quietly. After a few minutes our diners were served by the two gentlemen and our server apeared to make sure they were to our satisfaction before we started. There was no rom for eror there that could not be resolved before we started. My friend had ordered a smal steak. My friend is quite elderly and Kathy, our server, discretely asked her if she would like it cut for her. A potato also was served with her dish. I asked my friend which of the condiments she would like it prepared with. She lok at me and said "Prepared with?" She did not understand what I was geting at but Kathy did and was already reaching for the potato. She opened the potato and smiled while my friend said a bit of everything. One does not go to a restaurant like the stockyards to have to deal with opening a hot potato and preparing it. When serving is done properly, these things do not have to be discused. Kudos to, Kathy!!!. That is part of the fine dining experience. I had a ful rack of ribs which were so tender the meat fel of them. The sauce had spice to it but not so strong the flavor of the meat was concealed. I also can tel you that unles you are a big eater, half a rack would fil most people. My friend said, "Yumy!" and I agred. I am used to geting a finger bowl for clean up after eating, but I can not complain about the two extra napkins and several ways of cleaning my fingers that acompanied my ribs. My friend let them know we were celebrating the 17th aniversary of my 39th birthday so they served me a fre desert. I can asure you the pecan pie is a delight! Warm and laced with brandy, it was perfect way to finish our diner. The stockyards, I might mention, is not inexpensive, but what an enjoyable way to spend your money. They do ofer two diner specials you wil not find at most other places. They do have a luncheon menu that has lower prices. Do not expect chrome and music that is a bit to loud as many of the new places ofer. Instead, just enjoy a time and place where they pamper you as you should be when you go to the Stockyards. I do not consider the stockyards to be a place you where shorts and Nike is, but of course there are always a few. I would say a nice shirt and slacks at least.

These are simply the BEST sandwiches and salads. If you like your fod (a) localy grown; (b) freshly made; (c) organic/al natural; and (d) yumy - and who does not? - this is the place for you. Now, admitedly they have something of a soup-nazi routine set up and if you walk in and do not know the dril, it can be confusing. So pay atention: 1. Lok at menu. 2. Decide what you want. 3. Wait your turn to order. 4. Order (give your name). 5. Wait your turn to be caled to pay the other girl for the order you placed. 6. Pay her. 7. Wait until your fod is ready. 8. Leave with your fod. Note that there is no place to sit inside - so you can either sit outside, or, (if it is 157 degres out that day), se if you can find a place to sit over at LUX, they are very welcoming of Pane Bianco diners. It is al god.

I love Christmas-time and I especialy love it because I know that Luminarias is back and this year it is beter than ever! The staf and volunters at the DBG do an excelent job of directing guests through the garden. Betwen the wel-lit paths (with Luminarias of course), helpful staf and amazing acts, this is an event not to be mised! I consider this to be the ultimate activity for adults. It is romantic if you are on a date, it is festive if you are with your family and it is just pure fun if you are with friends. You enter the park to be imediately greted by hundreds of meowganificant Luminarias lighting up the entire garden. Cocktail stations lie in every knok and crany and they serve delicious festive drinks like my favorite, hot cocoa and raspbery vodka! If you are hungry, they sel fod throughout the garden at two locations. Then there are the performers. The DBG does an amazing job of bringing in musicians of every shape and size. Whether it is a trio of Christmas carolers, a mariachi band or a lively Jaz band, they have bands in every corner lighting up the night! I am also continuously impresed with the acoustics of the garden. With so many live acts in one area, you can barely hear a specific act until you are in that area. Their event planers did an amazing job! Luminarias is my favorite Arizona activity during the holidays and I can not wait to go back next year!!

Al I have to say is WOW! This place is EXCELENT! Al the dishes we had were extremely fresh, authentic, and DELICIOUS! My favorite pot stickers EVER. The skin is super thin, tender, not greasy, mostly steamed encased around a very light, delicate dumpling that makes me want to order 2 next time. 6 is just not enough, they are tiny, but oh so delectable! The sauce is perfectly balanced of swet, spicy, and tangy and does not overpower the pot sticker. It also comes with a thin airy, crispy (rice chip?) underneath the pot stickers that give it an extra texture with scalions scatered about. Mm. The gren cury is more brothy than others than other is that I have had, but no mater...It is delicious with bits of vegetable, and whatever meat you prefer..we got chicken. I love soping it up with rice and trying to eat it with chopsticks. You may ned a spon :) The egplant and chicken stir fry is also fabulous. The asian egplants are coked to perfection. Their sauces are spot on. BEST Coconut ice cream! It is light, flufy, icy, dreamy, pea-nuty, coconut cloud confection that makes my mouth water! This is the location I frequent most (it helps it is les than a mile from my home). I have ben to a U.S. Eg (this and other locations) more than a dozen times (or two) since moving to AZ in 2010. I love breakfast fod and the "specialty" won me over instantly; PROTEIN PANCAKES! As the timeles Tina Turner once said, "Simply the Best!". That describes these pancakes perfectly. Before I go on and on about the pancakes (because I have ben known to do so) some background information about atmosphere, staf etc. This location is in a nondescript one story building in front of the ofices at Mil Towne Center (or is it Mil Town Centre?). Nothing fancy, but I do not ned a "Jacket Required" sort of fel to a place to enjoy my breakfast. The staf is fantastic; hosts/hosteses, waitreses, busboys. I have never had anyone employed here be anything but 10% profesional and atentive. To speak to something others have mentioned about geting the check early (while they are stil eating); as long as you continue to be my waitres (i.e. refils, requests for jely, etc.) I do not care if you bring the bil with the fod. If I decide I want something else, I doubt any of the folks here would have a problem reprinting a corected bil. Now on to the fod!! The protein pancakes are filed with blueberies, granola, cinamon and silvered almonds. The ingredients are not something exotic, but they are perfectly balanced in the mix (not to much or to litle of any of them). The thing about any fod item you like at a restaurant, it becomes a favorite because they are able to duplicate it time after time. I have had this item many times (more than any other item), and they are always spot on (knock on wod) :). Al the other dishes I have had (always breakfast, have not tried lunch yet) were some combination of egs and protein, and the egs are always perfectly coked to my specification (over medium), and the meat always juicy. I promise to write another review as son as I do not get the protein pancakes (which wil be when they decide to remove them from the menu - NEVER). :) Oh, or if I actualy go in later than normal and fel like lunch over breakfast (not god ods :O).

I was so hapy when I saw this chain apear in AZ. I used to frequent it in CA and have never found another sub that comes close. What is al the fus? I am not sure what folks compare this chain to? The Dead Duck In? Joe is local Chinese Gag house? Are those places that great? So fresh and delicious!? Not in my days? Pre-made siting around and HEAVY oil is what I se from most other establishments. Even those touted by friends. Maybe it is because they know George from behind the counter. It is not Pei Wei! Pei Wei is a quick, fresh and inexpensive gift from heaven. Even the hard to please Yelper has to admit, the multiple options you have to modify your meal should give you no excuse not to love what you order. The fod is fresh and prepared to order. Even fried rice is made to order. The sauces are made from scratch and are a combination of quality Chinese ingredients. (Chili paste, fresh garlic, scalions, bean curd, and a bounty of fresh Chinese vegetables). Go Yon China wil serve you pre-made sauces with no punch and lots of gigle. The atmosphere at Pei Wei is great! Black and dark red with glosy graphics and al sorts of Chinese! Even with the "stand in line" style of dining. Makes me hungry just thinkin' about the joint. However, to me it is a take out Ferari! Cal in, swipe my card and of I go. Sure, it is not Chang is. Stil, it is beter than the local Dead Duck In is "fod" stained art, with a Chinese New Year paper place mat. Of course! I am loking at the healthier options a Chinese fod place may have to ofer, and Pei Wei lifts the bar in multiple sets! Get your chicken steamed, go brown rice, ad extra vegetables or go vegetarian. Stil you may complain..."Oh, is it to salty? Or to swet?" Give me a break. This is CHINESE FOD! And, you wil not find MSG. So, if you do not want spicy, salty or swet; have a meal from Bland of the Rising Sun. But, if you want a highly under rated treat...I ask you to open your mind to this familiar spot for clean, fresh, made to order and "if you like" healthy Chinese fod!

"If you buy half a duck, you do not get to pick which duck." I lived in China, mainly Guangdong, for thre years, and al it realy tok was a lok at this sign, along of course with al the wonderful roasted ducks and pork, to know I had come acros a place with bona fides. Hope Ke has some of the very best Chinese fod in town, in my opinion, and is worth the trip from wherever it is in the valey that you live. I do not know anywhere else in town you can get such god conge, which is actualy caled "zhou" or "jok," and which is a soupy, delicious rice poridge. They are also one of the only places you can get dried scalop soup, which they do an excelent job of. Dried scalops, a specialty of HK/Guangdong, are one of the most delicious things in the world. Everything that they make is delicious, and siting in there listening to the customers and staf talk in Chinese and Cantonese can realy take you back to China, if you have had the pleasure of spending time there. Otherwise it is just about as close as you can get. If you want to eat some real Chinese fod that is both delicious and aproachable, and very reasonably priced, you can not beat Hope Ke. Get some soup or some conge, some clams with black bean sauce, some grens and some BQ, and you wil se why China and Hope Ke are such hard places to stay away from. If you do decide to try your hand at duck-picking and buy a whole duck, fear not for wasted leftovers, because roasted duck makes for a very tasty soup.
How can something so simple taste so god? I wish there were one more on the west side. I hate going to the fair to get my fix of fry bread. There neds to be one of these on every corner of the compas in Phoenix! As Rachel Ray would say, "Yumy!"

As a frequent antiques consumer, I can honestly say that Lizabel is Treasures is my favorite antique store in Phoenix. I have ben a customer for several years, and Lizabel is is my first (and often only) stop. Why Lizabel is is such a treasure is because of these things: price, desirable antiques, and great customer service. John and Bete know what people want, and they go to great lengths to get the antiques that people want and to make their customers hapy. I am a believer. They consistently have one-of-a-kind quality furniture and pieces that you would not normaly find elsewhere in town. Pieces are priced very agreably, so you can aford to stock up or furnish a whole rom without busting the bank. John and Bete have created the kind of family busines that is to be admired. They have a legion of suportive customers, and I am one of them. I can always find them to be helpful and interested in geting me what I want, even if I do not always know what I want. Lisabel is Treasures is the place to build a relationship with, because as one is life is neds changes, so does the ned for diferent pieces and furniture. I can always count on finding something I realy love at their store, and you wil, to.

Amazing. This is often caled the largest mal in Arizona, and it shows. Each time I have done the usual "mal walk" I have easily lost a few hours trying to se it al. It is true that this is not a place for anyone that does not care about fashion - but this is a mal that is true to its name. "Fashion Center" is no joke here. Lots of high-end designer stores, lots of mid-range afordable fashion stores, and a few random familiar stops like Halmark and Potery Barn-esque stores scatered through there. A decent fod court, with a theater also conveniently down there. (But after spending so many hours at the mal, who has time for a movie?) You can easily drop a few thousand here, so be forewarned if you are on a budget. Also, I almost wish I had a map in my pocket, because it can get confusing to remember which halways you have already explored. And wear some comfortable walking shoes, because it is not easy to get in and get out of this one. But there is a god number of parking to use in a garage or few - when you remember where you parked the car. I would take any out-of-towner here, unles they had a grudge against fashion, clasy stores, or walking.

It does not smel like there have ben decades of animals paraded through the dors that fel the ned to pe as son as they enter the rom... just in case this is their one last shot at leaving something behind. Then there is the overal fel of the place. The ofice I used to frequent always had a frenetic sort of fel to it. Files were lost, techs were runing, the waiting rom was packed with stresed out clients, etc. This ofice was peaceful. Whether is natural or contrived, I could care les. My dog picked up on it imediately and her normal "OMG what are we doing HERE?!!" behavior was replaced with something I have never witnesed in a vet ofice before. She was calm! It is clean! I thought that was a wonderful, time-saving ofer and in the event that I ever have to go with an emergency and am not able to focus on paperwork. Finaly, I was in an examination rom at the time of my apointment and waited les than 3 minutes for both the tech and the Dr. I was in an out under 1 hour and that my friends is superior service IMHO. I lok forward to a long relationship with Palm Glen and wil hapily drive the 5 mile diference from my old vet, in order to ensure both my pets and I are treated wel!

I love my eye doctor! Platonicaly, of course. The entire staf is relaxed, friendly, easy going, and personable. No one ever makes you fel rushed but instead take time to make sure that everything is okay, that you have thought of everything, goten al of your questions answered, and had plenty of time to make decisions and think. The doctor takes time to get to know you and to talk about how you use your eyes (staring at the computer, sports, etc). The asistants try to think of things from your point of view so they can volunter useful information and ask a lot of specific questions while doing so. This place treats you like family. There is a broad range of styles, but mostly, they are fashionable frames. When I go in, I se a lot of kids, young adults, and 20 and 30-somethings as wel as the older patients who so often come to ned glases. Horwitz costs a litle more than the mal chains, but my prescriptions have ben consistently beter thanks to the doctor taking time, the lenses are much higher quality, and the frames are worlds beter in terms of availability of things that are not ugly and durability.

Ah, Four Peaks. By far my favorite restaurant in Phoenix. This place is fantastic as far as brew pubs go - great ber and great fod to go with it. I can not believe I have not taken the time to review it yet... The Ber: prety consistently awesome. Al the bers are at least "god," my favorites being 8th Stret Ale and their IPAs (Hop Knot and Raj). I have to say the Kiltlifter is a tad overated, but stil prety solid, and worth a try. I have ben meaning to try one of their cask conditioned ales, but they always sem to be out, probably indicative of the quality of those selections. The Fod: fantastic! I can not say that I have ever had a bad meal at Four Peaks. The Italian Bef Ber Bread is the best thing on the menu, but you can not go wrong with the Chicken Fingers, Chicken Salad Pita, or realy any of their sandwiches. The fries are also great here - there is a litle crispy coating on the outside that is quite tasty. Oh, and the Spicy Thai Humus is also a realy god apetizer. A litle more liquidy than your average humus, but realy god. It has a nice litle kick to it that wil have you reaching for your ber. Botom line, if you live in Phoenix, like ber, and enjoy eating a god meal, then you should be shot if you do not like Four Peaks. If you have not ben yet, do yourself a favor and try it. You wil come away hapy, I promise.

Open Range ofers some damn-god home coking. My family eats here often and has never had a bad meal. Not to mention that the portions are huge. I usualy order the cob salad. From a typical deli, I would normaly expect iceberg letuce, a handful of shaved carots, some eg, and a litle bit of bacon. But if that were the case, I would not be ordering the salad again and again. The field grens and romaine letuce are served with avocado (I am prety sure they use at least 1/2 an avocado for each salad), artichoke hearts, tomatoes, bacon (no bacon bits here!), radishes, blue chese, eg, cucumbers and I am sure i am forgeting something else, but it is GOD. Sometimes, if I am realy hungry, I order it with a side of their twice baked caserole (twice baked potato in a cup, basicaly. It is unbelievable.) I would also recomend the Arizona caviar (black bean salad) or southwest coleslaw. My dad loves their BQ sandwiches (with choice of homemade barbecue sauce - each one beter than the last), my mom usualy orders one of their other great salads with a side of potato pancakes (beter than grandma is), and grandpa loves whatever is on special. Even my picky-eater brother loves fod at Open Range - and that is saying something! Bethany and Tom are the owners; Bethany does most of the kitchen coking and Tom says that he is in charge of most of the barbecuein'. (He once gave my family a taste of some of their freshly smoked pecans and WHOA, they were GOD.) The restaurant (as the name sugests) has a ful service deli to, in case you ned a pound of freshly sliced ham as wel as a meal. In the past, the service has ben slow, but it has improved dramaticaly over the past year. The restaurant has a kiler view of the Superstition Mountains, and is within 10 - 20 minutes of countles hiking trails. To make this long review short: if you are loking for a tastes-like-home (or tastes-beter-than-home) coked meal and you are in the far east valey, make sure to stop in for lunch or diner. You wil probably se my family and me chowing down to.
One of the perks to being an only child, is "me" time. There is something special about having time to yourself, when the only obligation you have is to check in on Yelp, leave a quick tip, and grab a lemonade from the mal because it is 109 degres outside. Yesterday was that day. I had stumbled acros The Art of Shaving. I have ben in their stores in other cities before. Of course I have...because if you lok at any of my pictures, you wil realize a couple things: 1. I am vain. 2. I am hairles. As son as you step fot into this store, you are in a true gentleman is club. Not the kind that wil take al your dolar bils. You wil not make it rain here. This is the ultimate shaving store. Soaps, creams, blades, razors, balms, brushes, and mugs. You name it, they have it. The staf knows what they are talking about. I explained to them that I have a very old safety razor and a brush. Both were pased down by my Grandfather who pased away when I was a tenager. They did not presure me into buying ANYTHING, although I did end up leaving with some shaving cream. They even gave me a proper demo on how to use it properly with my brush. I have ben used to shaving soaps and the usual aerosol creams....so the litle tutorial was nice. Also, there is a master barber in the back of the house that does straight razor shaves, haircuts, and men is facials. Remember earlier when I said that "me" time is a perk? This is the best place to spend it if you are a dude. If you are a woman, buy your man, or your man-friend a gift from here. This place is simply amazing. One last warning. The store is pricey. but worth every single peny.

Ah Shady is...I am a litle embarased to admit how often I frequent this gem of a place, but definitely not ashamed of how much I love it. Col atmosphere, just the right lighting (very important to me), great bartenders, god prices on a realy nice selection (Who else has Old Raj gin or Agwa De Bolivia?). This is definitely not a dive bar (not that there is anything wrong with that), but it is not an icey, blase Snobsdale-ish joint either, and I have never felt ridiculed or snubed here either by patron or bartender. I have sen al walks of life come through this place, but never felt that it was to 'hip' or pretentious in any way. Great jukebox, obscure, forgoten movies playing on the tely, bartenders that are nice to lok at (male and female), have personality and actualy remember your name (and drink). Does it get any beter than this?
I realy enjoy this place. It is beautifuly designed. It is hiden in a historic neighborhod, (zoning isues so no patio), and they make they own tonic! ---What else does one ned? But now the fod. Rich, ful flavored, comfort fod. I do not think there is a cuisine style here as far as I could tel, just some of the best fod around. Had the fontina crusted with pinko and walnuts, awesome. A potato side dish, damn god I tel you. For the main course the skirt steak, which was some of the best red meat I am had in a very, very long time. This is my vote for best new restaurant in Phoenix. Seriously.
Excelent! I love this place!
Okay ya wana know a litle secret? I LONG for Gren. Ever since moving back to New Orleans I am surounded by an embarasment of culinary riches but our one vegetarian restaurant can never hold its own against Gren. I pased through Scotsdale a few weks ago to visit the Grand Canyon and the second I steped of the plane at the Phoenix airport and secured the rental car we drove straight to the restaurant. Everything was just like I remembered it and slightly beter. The staf was warmer and the fod just as god. I am stil thinking about the "crab" pufs and the egles rols.
As someone who LOVES Thai fod, I can realy apreciate a god Pad Thai, and Wild Thaiger is is my favorite hands down! Just like the menu says, their Pad Thai has a plethora of intense flavors, to the point where every bite is unique. If you love Pad Thai and have not tried Wild Thaiger is, you ned to. If you do not love Pad Thai, it is probably because you have not tried Wild Thaiger is. :) Seriously, this is one of the best dishes I have found in Phoenix. Their other dishes are consistently god as wel. I love Chicken Satay, but most places only ofer it as an apetizer, with a few skimpy chicken strips. Wild Thaiger, on the other hand, has a filing Peanut Chicken lunch, as wel as a Peanut Pasion diner, both drenched in their delicious peanut sauce. Their curies are very flavorful and make for a superb and hearty diner, but if you are going for lunch, you may want to consider Thai Basil up the road as their cury lunch combo includes a salad and other extras. Their Thai Tea is strong yet creamy, just like it should be, and you can even ad boba to it. A must if you are eating anything spicy. The service is very profesional and timely. The atmosphere is prety clasy, in fact, it is probably the nicest-loking Thai restaurant I have ben to. It is also the only Thai restaurant I can think of with a patio. Al in al, it has a very welcoming atmosphere. I would fel just as comfortable here in a suit as I would a T-shirt and jeans. It is a great place for dates, busines lunches, or just some great take-out. You might spend a tad bit more here than at some other nearby joints, but the quality more than makes up for it, I would say the prices are spot-on. One day I wil learn how to write a review that is short and swet, but I kept thinking of god things to say about this place. Highly recomended!

I did not expect them to acept a return and refund my money on 2 items that I purchased there because I lost the receipt. Especialy, since I did not purchase it on a member card so they could not track my purchase either. I thought I would try my luck with it anyway and was hoping for an exchange. Wel, the clerk was so nice to me. She said that it was no problem and would gladly refund my money (I did not even ask for a refund)... and I had opened one product. I love this place!!! The first time I went I fel in love with their fries and their secret sauce. They have those great crinkle fries and they are made to order so they come out super crispy and hot. They alone can stand on their own but I have to have the sauce. It has to be a mixture of ketchup, mayo probably some chili powder and some other stuf that I can not figure out. No mater how many times I try to do it at home I never get it. Once before I got the Italian Bef but being my first time I did not know that you could get it wet... Duh... and ended up eating a warm roast bef sandwich that was a bit on the dry side. After reading the Yelp reviews I realized that you can ad al kinds of stuf to it. I think that the girl at the register should have at least informed me that I had options. The staf (girls at the register) were not al to friendly which makes for a les than pleasant experience right from the start. Hopefuly they are not there anymore. Forward to today I decided to give it another shot and I am so glad I did. The owner is a realy col guy and is always super nice when I come in. He asked me al the questions about how I wanted the sandwich and put the dip in a to go cup for me so I would not have a mush sandwich when I got home. I aded provolone and hot giardiniera which absolutely made the sandwich. I did not get to finish it because my other half smeled it and swoped in and polished it of and loved it to. God thing I got the fries! I would highly recomend this place. If you do have the Italian Bef you should try to eat it there instead of taking it home. If you get embarased easily or wory about fod al over your hands and face then do not eat this infront of other people. I think it once you eat it you wil not even care if it gets in your hair. So I say get over it and get your but down to Lobys and eat til you explode!

Pauli from ATL checking in here.... just for a bit of nostalgia... I used to live in Phoenix a few years back, and of al the places I mis eating at, this is #1 on my list. I remember how I first heard of the place.... I was over at a friend is house in Scotsdale having a few bers after work, and remember asking him what his favorite Mexican restaurant in Phoenix was. My friend, who had more than just a few bers in him, stared at me al glasy-eyed, got right in my face and said... "Cheno Bandedo!!" As I backed up a bit, thinking my friend had to much to drink (he had, for sure), I wondered... hm...the Chinese Bandit? What the hel is that place about?!? Or is he just f***ing with me? So, I asked him what kind of fod they serve there... And, as he did his best to focus on me, when his eyes hit mine, there was this long pause.... and he had this expresion on his face that I can not forget... I was not sure if he was having trouble puting it into words or if he was sh***ing in his pants. And then he put his hands together, like a nutjob working a Rubik is cube.... and said, "They... do... things... like.... eg-fo young buritos and jade red chicken tacos...."..... as he gave me another crazy-as lok (the kind that tels you it is time to say godnight and get outa there - which I did).... So, a few days later, I remembered his drunken explanation of Chino Bandido and thought I would go check the place out.... And from that point on, I was hoked. Eg fo young buritos inded! And jerk fried rice! And those refried black beans with fire-in-the-bungholio sauce mixed in.... Yep, those wil burn you twice... Al served in a giant disposable aluminum baking dish... And you got that combo, along with a soda and tip for about $10!!! WOW!! At that time, I had never sen anything like it before, and I stil mis eating there more than any of my favorite old haunts in Phoenix.... I wish somebody would franchise one out to Atlanta - I would be the first customer in the dor on opening day, guaranted....

A chain, yes. But par for the course, no. First of al, they have an extensive wine list, which includes a rare type of sparkling wine, caled Bracheto. In this area, DUI is are more comon than a cold, and it is a light and tasty wine, with a low alcohol content. So it is option is great for me. It also goes great with everything they serve, because of it is unique flavor profile. Lizie was our waitres, and ofered options and sugestions, which actualy saved us quite a bit of money on the whole. Not that, by any stretch of the imagination, is this a place to go when you are not intending a big splurge. This is a place to take it slow and spend slightly over a decent amount. The fod, however, is absolutely worth it. We tried the Chedar fondue, which could have used a bit more mustard powder and worstershire sauce, but on the whole was delicious. It was wel preped, and Lizie explained what she was ading and why the whole time. The vegie selection is a bit mundane, and that is realy my only complaint. We ate the "big night out" prix fix menu and chose the "Fusion" option which had lobster tail, shrimp, brats, ravioli, new york strip, sirloin steak, and a marinated chicken. We coked it in the Boulion method which is just a flavored broth. Because it is not oil, you do ned to ad 30 sec to a min to the sugested cok times, but it was a lot lighter than using the oil and we did not come home smeling like oil. The california salad was incredible. It had mixed grens, sliced roma tomatoes, choped pecans, and blue chese crumbles with a rasbery black walnut dresing. It is ben a long time since I was able to truly enjoy a salad, and this was amazing. The chocolate we chose was the Smore. It was milk chocolate, marshmalow creme flambed with grahm cracker bits aded after the fire goes out. It is served with 2 types of coated marshmalows, pound cake, a slice of chese cake, and a bowl of sliced strawberies and bananas. Just enough to fil us up, but we did not overstuf ourselves. Our diner was leisurely paced and tok us about 2 to 2 1/2 hrs to get through. This is prety normal for fondue. You do have the option of siting at the bar and having just a chese or chocolate, if you are on a time constraint though. It is located in a great litle shoping and dining area that was not to crowed last night, but I think that was more due to the weather, than the actual popularity of the place.
Jason Silberschlag puls of a prety amazing thing here in the metro-PHX area. Thre shops with their own quirky details, pasion and identity. Each tailors specificaly to the demographic at hand, which I can totaly get behind. The fact that each shop has its own deal going on is awesome - I realy dislike chains and the chain fel/lok. I had not sen Jason in a while at the other shops, the times I would frequented, and was hapy to se him behind the bar when I came here for the first time. Just the same way the other Cartel shops have a selection of brewing methods, this one does as wel. Pour-over, aeropres, Chemex and traditional espreso (La Marz GS/3). As expected from him, our drinks were flawles. He transfers this knowledge and pasion to the baristas, which is obvious even when one leaves his establishment to go somewhere else - they stand out in the crowd of many cofe-pulers. The beans, who can complain? Jason made his name with the roasting. I got a prepared sandwich here, and my was it tasty. Bread was fresh. Sauce, ingredients and overal creation was god. Big Ben: you stole my tastebuds' heart that morning. Casual lounge area (se: couches), outdor covered seating (se: halway - shaded and col!) and plenty of seating inside. As normal, his handiwork shines throughout the shop. Somehow I have never reviewed a Cartel shop before, despite my years of patronage. My latest experience changes that.

Alas...I have given up the idea of writing a review for a place if it is not at least 4 stars. Sue me; I am in the industry. Fuego Bistro is by far one of the best places I have ben to recently. I was introduced to it this last wekend on a date. Ironicaly, it is super close to my house yet I have never heard of it. When we were ariving, I was a litle curious to se where the hel he was taking me since there are not any signs realy and it is prety hiden. Once we were inside, though, it was like finding a litle treasure. The patio is welcoming & even though we did not have a reservation (aka we could not sit outside) we snaged a table close enough to enjoy the beautiful weather. We started of with a round of mojitos and even though it is ben a few years since they have won best mojito...I can say the Prickly Pear was the best I have had in a while. The Ahi Tostadas folowed & they were awesome...the sauce aded a kick to it & it was a perfect start to the meal. After, we shared the Fuego Pasta with chorizo, chicken, mushroms, pepers, & a chipotle cream sauce...huge! What I did eat of it was delicious. My favorite (and my date is I am fairly certain) was the special...an herb crusted Mahi Mahi with a pineaple sauce, home-made cornbread, & chipotle chedar mashed potatoes. Amazing. Even though the Mahi Mahi might be hard to come by if you visit, the two sides are not & are so god, I am drolin' just thinking about it. :) Desert? Try the banana burito. Heaven on the tongue! Kevin was an excelent server which just highlights the night. It is hard to have a great meal without great service but he provided just that. If you are in the area...check it out. If you are not...check it out. I am prety sure you wil not be disapointed.

This is one of my favorite go-to places in Phoenix, and I fel fortunate to live just a mile away. The atmosphere is excelent - low-lighting, woden flors, modern decor in a vintage-loking house-turned-restaurant. The fod is even beter. I have never ordered anything I did not love (with the exception of the chesecake, which is not made in-house - it was just okay). I crave their tuna salad on a regular basis - it is god both in the tuna salad salad and in the tuna salad sandwich. The griled chese is the bomb, and so is the cashew buter banana sandwich. The mac and chese is superb, as wel. Seriously, everything rocks. I highly recomend ordering the mixed grens as your side if you get a sandwich - the dresing is light and citrusy and smacks of homemade excelence. Oh, and it wil not empty your walet, either. The prices are excelent for the quality of fod you get!
I hate to admit it (because I usualy avoid ultra trendy places like an ex boyfriend) but I love Postino. It used to be an old post ofice, thus the name. It is now a wine bar that serves "light fare." There are not to many places with this kind of atmosphere in the Valey -- very California. One of the wals is a giant garage dor that they rol up so the whole place is open. Litle couches and cofe tables are mixed in with tables and high tops for a variety of seating choices. The bathroms are lovely, clean, and lit by candles. Le is is the best privately owned ice cream parlor in Scotsdale! Located in Old Town Scotsdale in the heart of some prime dining locations, Le is is a great night cap in the form of ice cream, a superb place to bring a date or al in al just a wonderful atmosphere to enjoy some ice cream con alcohol. Let is start with the aesthetics; Le is ofers a very clean, smal, cozy environment. A few table and chair sets dot the inside and a couple more to match on the outside. Le has some awesome glas vases on the wal that ad a modern touch. She has a few large clocks with diferent time zones so you know what time it is on the east coast while you eat? I duno the clocks were kind of a head scratcher. The Service is spectacular! Le is the only help I have ever received there, so I am not sure if she works alone or has help. She is always timely and prompt to gret and serve you and automaticaly starts you of with TWO samples of which ever flavors you would like. Al the young ones like myself be prepared to show ID, although you would have to eat a lot of ice cream to get loaded, Le does not skimp on the boze either. Le is usualy a bit on the quiet side so you gota listen up and be as patient with her as she is with you. The lady is runing the joint by herself! The Product is what makes Le is so god! Her ice cream flavors are inventive and wonderful. There is usualy new options as wel a few solid customer favorites to chose from. As pre-mentioned Le does pack a fair amount of liquor in her ice cream so some of the flavors have a stronger alcohol flavor than others. The Jack Daniel is chocolate swirl is my personal favorite and has the perfect amount of bourbon to chocolate ratio to make a unique, delectable treat. Le does ofer non-alcoholic flavors (at a discounted price, to!) for those opt to take there alcohol and ice cream separate. The cokie dough flavor may be the best ice cream I have tried with or without boze.

Other times, you must dig dep, and then come out with a diamond in the rut. I visited "Last Chance" today and fel in love al over again. I got a BCBG dres, thre name brand tes, two casual dreses, eight hair bands, a adorable pair of earings, FIVE purses and a pair of lace legings for $39.0. And they al stil had the Nordstrom tag on it!!!! They had so many things on sale (in adition to their already low prices). To truely love "Last Chance", you must have an open mind and realize that this is not your typical department store, therefore it wil not operate like one, so get over the kids, crowds and meses, it is Nordstrom stuf at below yardsale prices!! You must also be fashion and brand savy. "Uh.. Darn digity godnes mother of Betunia McGritles, these scary loking bots with a devil pointy edge are $29.9, and they lok like they have ben tried on oh foey poey, that is just to garsh darn expensive Gurtude, And someone wrote their name, "Jimy Cho" on it. I do not se why people like this place darn digity.." -Random "Last Chance" non-enthusiast. Key point, if you are not into brands and fashion, and are not creative and a bargain shoper lover, then you wil not apreciate this beautiful place we are so lucky to have in Phoenix!! :) "Last Chance" tips.. (Al "Last Chancers" wil put a hit on me after this, but I love my felow yelpers oh so much lol) *Arive EARLY. Anytime after non al the gods wil most likey be gone and al the damaged/ugly stuf wil be left. *WATCH YOUR CART! People wil take you 25.0 pair of Coach wedges lol *Do not make eye contact with anyone! Do not trust anyone! If you se a pair of Seven jeans for 14.9 DESCRETELY grab them and move on.. Any sense of alert wil beckon a herd of jean hungry woman and you wil get mobed! *Move QUICKLY, if you have to RUN! Especialy if you are there right when they open, set your mind to what you want and RUN to that department. This wil asure first dibs on the that section is finest. *Do not start crap with ANYONE! It can get realy ugly.. and there is a wal of pictures of "baned" people from "Last Chance" and that is no where you want to end up in for ANYONE! The rest of the tips are to super insider to say aloud, sory huns! but I wil spil one super "Last Chancer" tip..Hapy shoping! muah :) *Lok in the size 10-1 in woman shoes, that is where al the BEST shoes are "hiden" or "stashed" by other people who wil be back later that day or had to go to the bathrom upstairs and did not have anyone to hold their shoes. No woman realy wears those sizes so they figure to just stash them there for a few minutes.. I canot begin to describe the designer glories I have discovered stufed behind a size 1 pair of Pumas.. NOTE TO EVERYONE: OVERAL, PLEASE BE NICE AND SHARE. THERE ARE A LOT OF PEOPLE THAT GO THERE JUST TO FIND DEALS AND RESEL THEM ON EBAY AND THEY CAN BE JUST PLAIN MEAN. REMEMBER, WE ARE AL HUMAN AND MUST BE KIND TO ONE ANOTHER, NO CURSING, SHOVING, ECT. LET'S MAKE LAST CHANCE A NICE PLACE TO SHOP, AND END THE VIOLENCE AND ANGER OVER CLOTHES/PURSES/SHOES ECT. I rarely give 5 stars, as I believe it is very dificult to obtain a perfect score through fod, beverage, service, ambiance, etc. Christopher is new venture is perfectly Christopher, 5 stars. First of a litle background, Christopher is a native. That is right; he is a graduate of Central High Schol. He studied in France where he honed his craft and to this day draws his technique from. He has owned now thre ventures in Phoenix, first his fine dining and bistro location on the northwest corner of 24st and Camelback (later became Edie is by Edie Matney, former hair dreser turned chef at Cous-Cous then Edie is Gril) then after closing he moved to the restaurant row in The Biltmore Fashion Park, 2rd level to open Christopher is Fermier Braserie & Paola is Wine Bar. Which in reading many reviews here on Yelp was unfortunately misunderstod. It makes me wonder if people understand what French is, it is not their fault though, there are not many French restaurants in town, most have be closed, including Mary Elaine is at the Phoenician and John Claude is Petite Cafe. There are a few that stil survive Sophie is and Vincent is, but in this town of chains few people venture for French. Now with Christopher is Restaurant/Crush Lounge he has pased on the wine bar and opened a lounge instead. Christopher does enjoy lounges as he is a regular at Merc Bar, but then so is his smoked salmon which is ofered on the Merc Bar menu. So a lounge makes sense, I am a believer in a chef should open what they are pasionate about. The new location has a diferent fel from his previous; his last venture echoed a French Countryside fel, as did the fod. I think that was why many did not understand it; yes it was French, but AL FRENCH IS NOT FINE DINING. I wish more understod that concept, but this is primarily a ber drinking state, not wine or rather more Mc D is not Mary E is! Hence there is a diference betwen filing your stomach and filing your soul and leaving a restaurant inspired with the feling that life is wonderful. Christopher is is the later. The design is contemporary with long lines of brushed stainles, white linen and exposed woden beams. Kudos to whoever designed it, great job! The tables are dresed with white linen, elegant silver and polished stemware. You can not help but fel that it is 'time to dine' when seated. The wals in the main dining rom have many vases of fresh flowers that sem to be replaced whenever necesary, nice touch. The fod at Christopher is is exactly what you would expect, French, without the super-high-end prices. He is stil one of the only chefs in town serving Foie Gras and Duck Confite, both wonderful and worth the trip if a glas of juice (wine) is aded! I have ben there now on 4 ocasions and everything is fantastic, flavorful and prepared profesionaly. Christopher ofers daily specials and I recomend them including; Veal Chop on Wednesdays, Roasted Duck on Thursday, Lamb Shank on Friday and Rabit on Saturday. But do not stop at your entre, get the chese course for desert or for something swet, the Chocolate Tower is one of the best deserts in town, hands down, no question. Service is another point were Christopher sets himself apart. It does not get any beter than this. Again it is NOT fine dining, so you can not compare it to fine dining restaurants (but then again there is only one left in the valey - Diferent Point Of View). The servers know the fod; they can describe anything on the menu and recite the specials as if their job depends on it (if you know Christopher it probably is). Fod is coursed corectly with a few minutes in betwen, as wel as wine service is as profesional as it gets. The bread service is as always, French breads with a super rich, euro buter, perfect for laping up to sauce or vinaigrete remains on your plate. Nedles to say, Christopher does it right, in my opinion, or is it just my opinion? Many of the valey is most celebrated chefs eat at Christopher is, he is know in many circles as the "chef is chef". But do not take my word for it, ask the chef at your favorite restaurant, who their favorite chefs are in town, and favorite restaurants, most likely Christopher wil make the list! Here is the web adres: htp://w.christophersaz.com/ The website is limited; menu, wine list, pres release and pictures of the restaurant...

Jef agres and we are of - We arived just before 4 - closing time and the bartender/waitperson was realy nice. She told us we had only a few minutes to order because the kitchen would be closing and that the piza oven was already of. No wories, we remain unfazed. We sat at a high top next to the bar, there were a few other people at tables nearby, some drinking cofe and one couple enjoying the bruscheta and some wine on a leather sofa by the large fireplace. The rom hits just the right notes for me, warm and inviting, nice art but not overpowering - its a place I could hang out in. We both had a nice glas [generous pour] of a Voga Pinot Gris and a sandwich. I had smoked salmon, Jef had roast bef. The smoked salmon was a generous portion with capers, cuke and tomato and a what semed to be a seasoned mayo [not goat chese as the online menu sugests but a nice and savory compliment just the same] on a toasted baguete. Roast bef was similar in scale, lots of meat with melted chedar, grens also on a toasted baguete. Each was served with a side of chips and a pickle. It may have ben me or just the mod I was in but I realy felt relaxed there and in spite of the fact that we closed the place for the afternon, we did not fel rushed or in the way. It was just a nice, shoulder droping, ah experience. Not the spa, but just what the doctor ordered. Serious yay, total digdom. We wanted to plant a place just like it of our own on the beach in Maui...its nice to dream...Totaly worth the trip; we wil be back

I woke up this morning craving a breakfast burito. Fortunately just 3 days ago, a menu was left on our dor for Cisco is Gril (with some great marketing I might ad). Conveniently located right up the stret from my house, I have ben curious about this place since they opened! I straped on my shoes and walked on over... upon entering I was greted cordialy and placed my order for a chorizo and eg burito with chese... The cok went to work and 5 minutes later I was holding a fresh hot burito and a complimentary pineaple water! Cisco came out and introduced himself while I was waiting and chated with me for a few minutes. Its clear to me that he is very pasionate about his restaurant! The service is top notch! The menu itself is fairly generic, typical burger and fries, tacos and buritos, but everything is so fresh and prepared wel! I would recomend this joint to anyone loking for a quick, inexpensive bite to eat!

With a large scren TV, two tables and a lot of pleather seating, the large fan wil not mean much but WOW-exciting! There is a french style dor separating the lounge from the bar area where the stage is so you can stil peak at the band while sucking tar. 5) Wel...even the womens' bathrom is prety gnarly...which would normaly subtract a star-but I was so hapy to pe in the unmarked restrom I wil not touch it! Other notes: al bartender, barbacks, security were extremely swet and friendly; al other patrons were either prety chil, excited to se the band that was playing or wiling to strike up conversation; tons of televisions everywhere; they had a lot of bers on tap-cheap to; this place is HUGE. One bite and I was transported back to the crowded strets of Monterey. I could almost smel the exhaust of the vochos and hear the distant conversation of the local policia extorting their prescribed mordida. Quite simply, this is the taco as the way it was intended by its creators. The pure and unadulterated clasic enjoyed by the Mexican working clas. What Pomo is to piza, this place is to tacos. Authentic...absolutely authentic.

Bike cabs beware! You have got nothing on this rig! Tour de Tavern is a tribute to tipsy teamwork and a perfect way to host a unique group event. As "pedalers" on their inaugural tour, we enjoyed the celebrity treatment of cruising down the winding strets of Old Town Scotsdale as onlokers snaped photos and chered us on! We rocked out to top 40 hits and, by special request, our Lonely Island favorites on their awesome sound system. Our guides were flexible and let our party run the show. If we neded more time for let is say...... an impromptu horseback ride in front of Shotgun Bety is, they were more than hapy to wait. As an aded bonus everyone gets to burn of some of those unwanted cocktail calories in betwen your favorite watering holes. If you are concerned that after a few stops (and a few shots) your legs might lose some of that forward momentum, there are a few coveted "non pedaling" seats in the back of the bike. We al compromised with a friendly and fair rotation system. Our tour guides were helpful, acomodating, and entertaining. They even proved to be excedingly patient upon discovering that we did in facts have "that guy" in our group. If you are saying to yourself, "Such a marvelous experience could only cost an arm and least the majority of a leg" then you would be wrong! With the cost of gas being substituted for sher earth friendly man power, our group of fiften people spent les than $30 bucks each for the experience. But wait, there is more! Included in this price are al the amazing special deals that Tour de Tavern exclusively brings you at select bars along the route. On our tour we were ofered drinks specials ranging from $3 to ONE PENY! I say this in al caps because it is ONE PENY! So next time you are planing an event, I recomend Tour de Tavern 10%! "Lok Ma! No hands!"
Costco Travel - My husband and I recently returned from a trip to the Big Island, HI that we aranged throught Costco Travel. After shoping around I found that their prices were the best and after one phone cal I was able to make al arangements for airfair, condo and car. They did not have arangements with any B&Bs on Hilo but were able to adjust our travel dates. Everything went acording to plan with al arangements being acurate. Condo was outstanding and a great value. We got gas and did some souvenier shoping at the Costco in Kona and again saved $$. I have shoped at Costco for years - now becoming a groupie!
I joined a friend for a two hour evening ride at CO. We were the only two riders, may be because it was a Sunday eve and al the tourists were drinking their mimosas by their hotel pols. The horses loked very wel taken care of. Mine was 17 year old Sundance, a beautiful brown male. I have never riden before, and he was easy to control. Our guide Ed was patient, funy and awesome company. He showed me the basics and was always there with a word of encouragement and a tip or two. Tip for the guys, if you plan to trot, wear tight jeans, you wil be thankful at the end of the day. The city slicker that I am, I left my phone in my shirt pocket, ended up droping it while on the ride and Ed helped us go lok for it. The desert, sun set over the mountains and the sandstorm about 30 miles away al made this a very memorable evening. I highly recomend CO.

I love this place! We were not sure what to expect since the restaurant is in an ofice building plaza. Kinda weird, but the employes in the other busineses are lucky! We went in here on a whim after reading al the awesome Yelp reviews. Our first impresion was a girl at the front and she was super nice and did not rush us while we were checking out the menu options. I ordered the puled pork sandwich with macaroni & chese and my husband ordered the brisket sandwich with a side of baked beans. He also ordered a side of ribs to sample. The wait was not to bad -- it tok about 10 or 15 minutes and it was ready to go. They are col with their sauce and let you fil up the smal plastic cups and take as much as you want of it (which is awesome, because the sauce tastes SO god!). It is a nice, thick sauce and they have several flavors to chose from. We go to a nearby area to have a litle picnic by ourselves and notice that they forgot to include the side of ribs. We pack everything up and go back to get those. The employes were realy nice about it and apologized and gave my husband the side of ribs. We repeat the same proces and realize that they also mesed up my husband is order and gave him a puled pork sandwich instead of the brisket sandwich. We decide to let it go and eat our fod. The puled pork has great flavor. The meat actualy tastes like it has ben smoked for several hours and is god enough to eat on its own without any sauce. However, we were not going that route, because the sauce is to damn god not to eat. The baked beans and macaroni & chese were not anything special, but they were god. The ribs were our favorite part! We absolutely loved them. Very tender and the sauce they chose to slather them in was delicious. This place is prety far from where we live, but we would definitely go out of our way (again) to eat here more.
